query_id: Rofr/Rofo/Rofn
clause:
The Farids Group shall not deliver more than one ROFR Sale Notice or ROFO Sale Notice in any thirty (30) day period. If by the expiration of the ROFR Transfer Period, the Farids Group has not completed the Transfer of the ROFR Shares, in order for the Farids Group to Transfer such ROFR Shares (or any other Shares) it shall be necessary for a new ROFO Sale Notice or ROFR Sale Notice to be delivered, and the terms and provisions of this Article VII to be again complied with. Subject to the restrictions set forth in Section 5.1 of this Agreement and Section 2.3 of the Warrant, in the event any member of the Farids Group proposes to Transfer (other than a Permitted Transfer) (i) a Threshold Block, in a transaction or series of related transactions, that, to the Farids Group's knowledge (after due inquiry in connection with a private, non-open market transaction) is to a Person whom the Company reasonably determines is a direct or indirect material competitor of the Company or any Affiliate of such Person or (ii) a Significant Block, in a transaction or series of related transactions, that, to the Farids Group's knowledge (after due inquiry in connection with a private, non-open market transaction) is to a Person whom the Company reasonably determines is a direct or indirect material competitor of the Company or any Affiliate of such Person (in each case, regardless of whether such Transfer will constitute a 144 Sale), the Farids Group shall furnish to the Company a written notice of such proposed Transfer (a "ROFR Sale Notice") at least (5) business days prior to the business day that the Farids Group proposes to effect such Transfer. The Farids Group shall not deliver more than one ROFO Sale Notice or ROFR Sale Notice in any thirty (30) day period. If by the expiration of the ROFO Transfer Period, the Farids Group has not completed the Transfer of any ROFO Shares at the ROFO Sales Price or a higher price, in order for the Farids Group to Transfer such ROFO Shares (or any other Shares) it shall be necessary for a new ROFO Sale Notice or ROFR Sale Notice to be delivered, and the terms and provisions of this Article VII to be again complied with. In the event that Company does not timely delivery a ROFR Purchase Notice, the Farids Group may sell the ROFR Shares to the proposed transferee identified in the ROFR Sale Notice at the ROFR Sale Price and on the other terms and conditions set forth in the ROFR Sale Documentation no later than three (3) business days following the date the Farids Group proposed to effect such Transfer in the ROFR Sale Notice (the "ROFR Transfer Period"). The closing of the purchase of such ROFO Shares by the Company and/or any such designee shall take place no later than five (5) business days after delivery of the ROFO Purchase Notice, with payment for such ROFO Shares being made concurrently with such purchase to the Farids Group's account designated in the ROFO Sale Notice. The ROFR Sale Notice shall include: (i) (A) the identity of the proposed transferee, (B) the purchase agreement and other documentation for the proposed Transfer (the "ROFR Sale Documentation"), (C) the number of Shares proposed to be sold (the "ROFR Shares"), (D) the per share purchase price in cash at which the Farids Group is prepared to Transfer such ROFR Shares (the "ROFR Sale Price") and (E) the date the Farids Group proposes to effect such Transfer; and 28
(ii) an offer to sell to the Company and/or a designee of the Company all of the ROFR Shares at the ROFR Sale Price. In the event that the number of ROFO Shares offered to be purchased in the ROFO Purchase Notice is less than the number of ROFO Shares set forth in the Sale Notice (or the Company does not timely deliver a ROFO Purchase Notice), the Farids Group may sell the ROFO Shares that are not subject to any such ROFO Purchase Notice during the five (5) day business day period beginning on the date in the ROFO Sale Notice on which the Farids Group proposed to begin to effect such 144 Sale (the "ROFO Transfer Period"); provided that no such ROFO Share may be sold for less than the ROFO Sale Price. If the Company wishes to purchase (and/or cause a designee to purchase) all of the ROFR Shares at the ROFR Sale Price, the Company shall deliver a notice (a "ROFR Purchase Notice") to the Farids Group within three (3) business day after receipt of the ROFR Sale Notice. The closing of the purchase of such ROFR Shares by the Company and/or any such designee shall take place no later than the later of (i) the purchase date set forth in the ROFR Sale Documentation and (ii) five (5) business days after delivery of the ROFR Purchase Notice, with payment for such ROFR Shares being made concurrently with such purchase to the Farids Group's account designated in the ROFR Sale Notice. The ROFO Sale Notice shall include: (i) (A) the number of Shares proposed to be sold (the "ROFO Shares"), (B) the per share purchase price in cash at which the Farids Group is prepared to Transfer such ROFO Shares (the "ROFO Sale Price") and (C) the date the Farids Group proposes to begin to effect such 144 Sale; and (ii) (ii) an offer to sell to the Company and/or a designee of the Company all or a portion of the ROFO Shares at the ROFO Sale Price. If the Company wishes to purchase (and/or cause a designee to purchase) all or a portion of the ROFO Shares at the ROFO Sale Price, the Company shall deliver a notice (a "ROFO Purchase Notice") to the Farids Group no later 8:00 a.m. New York time on the business day that the Farids Group proposes to effect such 144 Sale specifying the number of ROFO Shares it wishes to purchase (and/or cause a designee to purchase) from the Farids Group If the Company does not timely deliver a ROFR Purchase Notice it shall be deemed to have waived all of its rights with respect to the offer contained in the ROFR Sale Notice. Subject to the restrictions set forth in Section 5.1 of this Agreement and Section 2.3 of the Warrant, in the event any member of the Farids Group proposes to Transfer (other than a Permitted Transfer) a Threshold Block, in a transaction or series of related transactions, of Shares in a 144 Sale, the Farids Group shall furnish to the Company a written notice of such proposed Transfer (a "ROFO Sale Notice") at least 48 hours prior to the opening of trading on the Nasdaq Global Market (or such other primary stock exchange upon which the Common Stock is listed) on the business day that the Farids Group proposes to begin to effect such 144 Sale. If the Company does not timely deliver a ROFO Purchase Notice it shall be deemed to have waived all of its rights with respect to the offer contained in the ROFO Sale Notice.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **ROFR (Right of First Refusal), ROFO (Right of First Offer), and ROFN (Right of First Negotiation)** because it outlines the specific mechanics, restrictions, and procedures governing these rights in the context of share transfers by the Farids Group. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

### 1. **Definitions and Distinctions**  
   - **ROFR (Right of First Refusal)**: The clause specifies that the Farids Group must provide a **ROFR Sale Notice** to the Company before transferring shares to a third party, allowing the Company (or its designee) to match the terms and purchase the shares instead.  
   - **ROFO (Right of First Offer)**: The Farids Group must issue a **ROFO Sale Notice** to the Company before initiating a **144 Sale** (a Rule 144 resale of restricted securities), giving the Company the right to purchase the shares at the proposed price.  
   - **ROFN (Right of First Negotiation)**: While not explicitly named here, the clause implies a negotiation dynamic (e.g., the Company’s right to counter or waive the offer).  

### 2. **Key Provisions**  
   - **Notice Requirements**:  
     - **ROFR Sale Notice**: Must be delivered **5 business days** before a proposed transfer (e.g., to a competitor).  
     - **ROFO Sale Notice**: Must be delivered **48 hours** before a **144 Sale**.  
   - **Transfer Restrictions**:  
     - The Farids Group cannot issue more than one ROFR/ROFO notice in a **30-day period**.  
     - If the transfer isn’t completed within the specified period (**ROFR Transfer Period** or **ROFO Transfer Period**), a new notice is required.  
   - **Company’s Rights**:  
     - The Company can match the terms (price, transferee) in a ROFR or ROFO scenario.  
     - Failure to respond within the deadline (e.g., **3 business days for ROFR**, same-day for ROFO) waives the Company’s rights.  

### 3. **Competitor Protections**  
   - The clause imposes stricter rules for transfers to **material competitors** (requiring due inquiry and Company approval).  

### 4. **Process Flow**  
   - **ROFR**:  
     1. Farids Group sends a ROFR Sale Notice with terms.  
     2. Company has 3 days to issue a **ROFR Purchase Notice** (or waive rights).  
     3. Closing occurs within 5 business days of the notice.  
   - **ROFO**:  
     1. Farids Group notifies the Company of a **144 Sale**.  
     2. Company must respond by **8:00 a.m. on the proposed sale day**.  
     3. Unpurchased shares can be sold in the open market (but not below the ROFO Sale Price).  

### 5. **Relevance to Query**  
   - The clause **defines ROFR/ROFO mechanics**, including triggers, timelines, and consequences.  
   - It highlights the **differences** between ROFR (matching third-party offers) and ROFO (pre-sale offering to the Company).  
   - While **ROFN** isn’t explicitly named, the negotiation aspect is embedded in the Company’s right to accept/decline offers.  

### Summary  
This clause is a **detailed framework** for how ROFR and ROFO operate in the agreement, addressing notice requirements, transfer limitations, and the Company’s preferential rights. It answers the query by clarifying the **practical application** of these rights in share transfers.

query_id: Rofr/Rofo/Rofn
clause: XSPA shall give prompt written notice to Calm each time it offers, proposes to offer, or has received an offer to enter into any agreement or arrangement under which XSPA or any of its affiliates would sell, offer for sale, market, promote or undertake any similar action with respect to any meditation or sleep digital products or similar products at any Store outside the Territory (each, a "ROFR Notice").<omitted>If Calm exercises its ROFR within the ROFR Period, the Parties shall enter into an amendment or addendum to this Agreement to include such additional region and/or Stores.<omitted>If Calm does not exercise its ROFR within the ROFR Period, XSPA may enter into such agreement or arrangement with respect to the applicable region and/or Stores set forth in the ROFR Notice with any third party; provided that, such agreement or arrangement are on the same terms offered to Calm (it being understood that in the event XSPA modifies such terms, XSPA shall provide a new ROFR Notice to Calm in accordance with this Section \u200b3.02).<omitted>Throughout the Term and for a period of six (6) months after the expiration or termination of this Agreement, Calm shall have a right of first refusal to expand the rights and obligations described in this Agreement to any Stores outside the Territory (the "ROFR").<omitted>Calm shall have thirty (30) business days (the "ROFR Period") from receipt of a ROFR Notice to exercise its ROFR with respect to the region and/or Stores described in the ROFR Notice.
explanation:
The clause you provided is highly relevant to the query about **ROFR (Right of First Refusal) / ROFO (Right of First Offer) / ROFN (Right of First Negotiation)**. Here’s how it aligns with these concepts:

### 1. **Right of First Refusal (ROFR)**  
   - The clause explicitly grants **Calm a ROFR** to expand its rights to **Stores outside the Territory** if XSPA receives or makes an offer from/to a third party.  
   - Key ROFR mechanics:  
     - **Trigger**: XSPA must send a **ROFR Notice** to Calm when it receives or proposes an offer for selling/marketing meditation/sleep products outside the Territory.  
     - **Exercise Window**: Calm has **30 business days (ROFR Period)** to match the terms and accept the offer.  
     - **Outcome**:  
       - If Calm exercises the ROFR, the parties amend the agreement to include the new region/Stores.  
       - If Calm declines, XSPA may proceed with the third party **on the same terms** (or re-notify Calm if terms change).  

### 2. **Right of First Offer (ROFO) Elements**  
   - While not a pure ROFO (where the rights holder gets the first chance to make an offer before third parties), this clause has a **ROFO-like feature**:  
     - XSPA must notify Calm **before** entering into any agreement with a third party, effectively giving Calm the first opportunity to accept the terms.  

### 3. **Right of First Negotiation (ROFN) Comparison**  
   - A ROFN typically grants the rights holder an exclusive negotiation period before the owner can talk to third parties.  
   - This clause is **not a ROFN**, as it doesn’t require XSPA to negotiate exclusively with Calm before seeking third-party offers. Instead, Calm’s right is triggered only after XSPA has concrete terms to share.  

### Key Takeaways:  
- The clause is a **classic ROFR** (with ROFO-like notice requirements).

query_id: Rofr/Rofo/Rofn
clause: All communication with the National Football League (the "NFL"), its 32 Member Clubs, NFL Legends and Gold Jackets shall be made exclusively and directly through PFHOF. For the avoidance of doubt, PFHOF has the exclusive and sole relationship with the NFL, its 32 Member Clubs, NFL Legends and Gold Jackets for any and all PFHOF and HOFV activities; provided, however, that any communication relating to any investment by the NFL in any Village Media Company project, may be made directly through the President of PFHOF or the Chief Executive Officer of HOFV; and, provided further, that the Village Media Company shall have the right to present opportunities related to any of the above for approval by PFHOF.
explanation:
The query mentions **ROFR/ROFO/ROFN** (Right of First Refusal/Right of First Offer/Right of First Negotiation), which are contractual rights giving a party priority in purchasing, receiving offers, or negotiating for certain assets or opportunities before others.  

### **Relevance of the Clause to ROFR/ROFO/ROFN:**  
1. **Exclusive Communication & Control (Implied ROFR/ROFO):**  
   - The clause mandates that **all communication** with the NFL, its clubs, and Legends must go **exclusively through PFHOF**, effectively giving PFHOF control over these relationships.  
   - This could function similarly to a **ROFR/ROFO** by ensuring PFHOF has the **first opportunity** to engage in or approve any deals involving these entities before others (e.g., Village Media Company).  

2. **Investment Exception (Potential ROFR/ROFN):**  
   - While direct communication is allowed for NFL investments in Village Media projects (via PFHOF’s President or HOFV’s CEO), the **Village Media Company must still present opportunities to PFHOF for approval**.  
   - This suggests PFHOF retains a **right to review or negotiate first** (akin to ROFR/ROFN) before Village Media can proceed with NFL-related opportunities.  

3. **Approval Mechanism (ROFR-like Protection):**  
   - The requirement for PFHOF’s approval over Village Media’s proposals implies PFHOF has a **veto or priority right**, ensuring it can block or shape deals—similar to how a ROFR/ROFO would operate.  

### **Conclusion:**  
Though the clause doesn’t explicitly label these rights as ROFR/ROFO/ROFN, it **functionally creates similar protections** by:  
- Restricting direct dealings (giving PFHOF first control).  
- Requiring PFHOF approval for third-party (Village Media) opportunities.  
- Allowing exceptions only under PFHOF’s oversight.  

This aligns with the **spirit of ROFR/ROFO/ROFN** by ensuring PFHOF maintains priority in NFL-related engagements. For explicit ROFR/ROFO/ROFN terms, the contract would need clearer language (e.g., "PFHOF shall have a right of first refusal on any NFL-related commercial opportunities").  

Would you like help drafting such a provision?

query_id: Rofr/Rofo/Rofn
clause: XSPA shall give prompt written notice to Calm each time it offers, proposes to offer, or has received an offer to enter into any agreement or arrangement under which XSPA or any of its affiliates would sell, offer for sale, market, promote or undertake any similar action with respect to any meditation or sleep digital products or similar products at any Store outside the Territory (each, a "ROFR Notice"). If Calm exercises its ROFR within the ROFR Period, the Parties shall enter into an amendment or addendum to this Agreement to include such additional region and/or Stores. If Calm does not exercise its ROFR within the ROFR Period, XSPA may enter into such agreement or arrangement with respect to the applicable region and/or Stores set forth in the ROFR Notice with any third party; provided that, such agreement or arrangement are on the same terms offered to Calm (it being understood that in the event XSPA modifies such terms, XSPA shall provide a new ROFR Notice to Calm in accordance with this Section ​3.02). Throughout the Term and for a period of six (6) months after the expiration or termination of this Agreement, Calm shall have a right of first refusal to expand the rights and obligations described in this Agreement to any Stores outside the Territory (the "ROFR"). Calm shall have thirty (30) business days (the "ROFR Period") from receipt of a ROFR Notice to exercise its ROFR with respect to the region and/or Stores described in the ROFR Notice.
explanation:
The query refers to **ROFR (Right of First Refusal)**, **ROFO (Right of First Offer)**, and **ROFN (Right of First Negotiation)**, which are contractual mechanisms that grant a party preferential rights in certain business transactions. The provided clause explicitly outlines a **Right of First Refusal (ROFR)** in favor of Calm, making it directly relevant to the query. Here’s how the clause aligns with the concepts in the query:

### **1. Right of First Refusal (ROFR)**
- The clause grants Calm a **ROFR**, meaning that if XSPA (or its affiliates) receives an offer or intends to sell/market meditation or sleep digital products in stores outside the agreed Territory, Calm has the **first right to match that offer** before XSPA can proceed with a third party.
- **Key ROFR Elements in the Clause**:
  - **Trigger**: XSPA must issue a **ROFR Notice** to Calm when it receives or proposes an offer for expansion outside the Territory.
  - **Exercise Period**: Calm has **30 business days (ROFR Period)** to decide whether to match the terms.
  - **Binding Effect**: If Calm exercises the ROFR, the parties must amend the agreement to include the new region/stores.
  - **Same Terms Requirement**: If Calm declines, XSPA can proceed with a third party **only on the same terms** originally offered to Calm (or issue a new ROFR Notice if terms change).

### **2. Distinction from ROFO/ROFN**
- **ROFO (Right of First Offer)**: Unlike a ROFR (where the right is triggered by an existing third-party offer), a ROFO requires the seller to offer the opportunity to the ROFO holder **before** seeking third-party offers. This clause is **not a ROFO** because XSPA’s obligation arises only after it has an offer or proposes to offer to a third party.
- **ROFN (Right of First Negotiation)**: A ROFN grants the holder an exclusive negotiation period before the seller engages with others. The clause does **not** include negotiation rights—Calm must accept or reject the existing terms, not negotiate new ones.

### **3. Relevance to Query**
The clause is a **classic ROFR provision** (not ROFO or ROFN) because:
- It is **reactive** (triggered by an existing or proposed third-party offer).
- It allows Calm to **match the terms** rather than negotiate them.
- It includes safeguards (e.g., same terms requirement, re-notification if terms change).

### **Conclusion**
This clause is a **ROFR** mechanism, giving Calm the right to preempt third-party deals under defined conditions. It does not function as a ROFO or ROFN, as it lacks the proactive offering or exclusive negotiation features of those rights.

query_id: Change Of Control
clause: For purposes of this Agreement, "Change in Control" means a merger or consolidation of the party with, or any sale of all or substantially all of the assets of such party to, any other person, corporation or entity, unless as a result of such merger, consolidation or sale of assets the holders of such party\'s voting securities prior thereto hold at least fifty percent (50%) of the total voting power represented by the voting securities of the surviving or successor corporation after such transaction.
explanation:
The **"Change of Control"** clause defines the circumstances under which a significant ownership or structural change in a party (e.g., a company) would trigger legal consequences under the agreement.  

### **Relevance to the Query:**  
1. **Definition of Triggering Events** – The clause specifies that a **merger, consolidation, or sale of substantially all assets** constitutes a "Change in Control," unless the original owners retain **at least 50% of voting power** in the surviving entity.  
   - This ensures clarity on when contractual rights (e.g., termination, adjustment, or consent requirements) may be activated.  

2. **Protection Against Unwanted Takeovers** – By requiring that original shareholders retain majority control to avoid a "Change in Control," the clause safeguards against hostile takeovers or shifts in corporate governance that could disrupt contractual relationships.  

3. **Contractual Implications** – Many agreements (e.g., employment, loans, partnerships) include **change-of-control provisions** that may:  
   - Allow termination/renegotiation of the contract.  
   - Trigger payouts (e.g., "golden parachute" clauses).  
   - Require consent from the other party before proceeding.  

### **Key Takeaway:**  
This clause ensures that significant corporate restructuring does not occur without contractual safeguards, protecting stakeholders from unforeseen disruptions. If a transaction meets the defined criteria, it may activate rights or obligations under the agreement.  

Would you like modifications or additional context for a specific scenario?

query_id: Change Of Control
clause: [ * ] expected to experience, or [ * ] is experiencing, such Change of Control shall notify [ * ] in writing of this before or within [ * ] after the Change of Control. For the avoidance of doubt, if following [ * ] there is a transfer of shareholding or interests in Distributor to any existing or new shareholder(s) which results in any person or persons subsequently gaining Control of Distributor, then Google may exercise its right to terminate in accordance with this clause 5.4. [ * ] may terminate this Agreement immediately upon written notice if there is a Change of Control of [ * ]. In this Clause the term "Control" shall mean the possession by any person(s) directly or indirectly of the power to direct or cause the direction of another person and "Change of Control" is to be construed accordingly. For the avoidance of doubt, a Change of Control shall be deemed an assignment hereunder unless [ * ] does not exercise its [ * ].
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query **"Change of Control"** as it defines the rights and obligations of the parties (likely **Google** and a **Distributor**) in the event of a change in the ownership or control of the Distributor. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

### **1. Notification Requirement**  
- The clause requires the party undergoing a **Change of Control** (likely the Distributor) to notify the other party (**Google**) **before or within a specified period** after the event.  
- This ensures transparency and allows Google to assess whether the change affects its contractual relationship.

### **2. Definition of "Change of Control"**  
- **"Control"** is defined as the power to direct another entity, whether directly or indirectly.  
- A **Change of Control** occurs when a new person or group gains this power (e.g., through a share transfer, merger, or acquisition).  
- The clause clarifies that even transfers to **existing or new shareholders** that result in a new controlling party trigger this provision.

### **3. Termination Rights**  
- **Google has the right to terminate the agreement immediately** upon a Change of Control of the Distributor.  
- This protects Google from being forced into a relationship with an unwanted new controlling entity (e.g., a competitor or financially unstable party).  
- The termination right is **at Google’s discretion** (since it says "may terminate").  

### **4. Deemed Assignment**  
- A Change of Control is treated as an **assignment** (transfer of rights/obligations) unless Google chooses not to exercise its termination right.  
- Many contracts restrict assignments without consent, so this ensures Google retains control over who it does business with.

### **5. Practical Relevance to the Query**  
- If a **Distributor is acquired or undergoes a major ownership change**, this clause allows Google to **exit the agreement** if it deems the new ownership unfavorable.  
- It also **forces disclosure**, preventing hidden ownership changes that could impact the business relationship.  

### **Conclusion**  
This clause is a **standard protective measure** in contracts where one party (Google) wants to control who it engages with. It ensures that any **shift in ownership or control** of the Distributor is communicated promptly and gives Google the flexibility to **terminate the agreement if necessary**.  

Would you like any modifications or further clarification on specific terms?

query_id: Change Of Control
clause: A change of control shall be deemed an assignment requiring consent hereunder provided that any transfer or assignment that results in Seller's and Buyer's current common parent, Reynolds Group Holdings Limited, ceasing to control either party shall not require consent of the other party. This Agreement, its rights and obligations, is not assignable or transferable by either Party, in whole or in part, except with the prior written consent of the other Party, which consent will not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed.
explanation:
This clause addresses the **"Change of Control"** query by defining how a change in ownership or control of either party (Seller or Buyer) affects their obligations under the agreement. Here’s the relevance to the query:

1. **Change of Control as Assignment**:  
   The clause treats a **change of control** (e.g., acquisition, merger, or significant ownership shift) as an **assignment** of the agreement, which typically requires the other party’s consent.  

2. **Exception for Common Parent**:  
   If both Seller and Buyer are currently controlled by the same parent company (**Reynolds Group Holdings Limited**), a transfer or assignment that results in this common parent **losing control** of either party **does not require consent**. This ensures internal corporate restructuring (within the same group) does not trigger consent obligations.  

3. **General Non-Assignability**:  
   The agreement otherwise prohibits assignment or transfer **without prior written consent**, which cannot be **unreasonably withheld, conditioned, or delayed**. This protects both parties from unwanted third-party involvement.  

### **Key Relevance to "Change of Control"**  
- It clarifies that a change of control (e.g., a takeover) is treated like an assignment, requiring approval unless it involves the common parent’s loss of control.  
- It balances flexibility (for corporate group restructuring) with protection (preventing uncontrolled transfers to unrelated entities).  

Would you like any refinements or additional explanations?

query_id: Anti-Assignment clause that requires notice only for assignment to affiliates
clause: Except as otherwise provided herein, a Party shall not have the right to assign any of its rights or obligations under this Agreement (whether through a merger, sale of stock, or otherwise) without the prior written consent of the other Party; except that, either Party shall be permitted, without any need for the other Party's consent, to assign this Agreement (a) in whole or in part to an Affiliate (provided, however, that once such Person is no longer an Affiliate of the assigning Party, such former Affiliate shall assign this Agreement back to the assigning Party), provided that the assigning Party provides the other Party notice of any such assignment provided further that failure to provide such notice of such assignment shall not render such assignment void; or (b) to a Third Party in connection with sale or transfer of all or substantially all of the assigning Party's business or assets relating to the subject matter of this Agreement, whether by Change of Control, merger, sale of assets or otherwise; provided, however, that, with respect to clause (b), (i) any assignment of this Agreement shall be void and have no effect unless and until the assignee assumes the <omitted> obligations of the assigning Party in a written instrument, a copy of which is provided to the other Party; and (ii) any assignment of this Agreement must be accompanied by a simultaneous assignment of the Other Agreements to the same assignee, and the assigning Party's interest in the Purchased Assets to the same assignee unless otherwise agreed by Conformis in advance, which agreement shall not be unreasonably withheld.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the query regarding an **anti-assignment clause that requires notice only for assignment to affiliates** because it:  

1. **Prohibits General Assignments Without Consent** – The clause states that neither party can assign its rights or obligations under the agreement without the other party’s prior written consent, except in two specific scenarios.  

2. **Permits Assignment to Affiliates Without Consent, But Requires Notice** – The exception in **subsection (a)** allows a party to assign the agreement to an **Affiliate** without needing the other party’s consent, **but mandates that the assigning party must provide notice** of such assignment.  
   - Importantly, the clause clarifies that **failure to provide notice does not invalidate the assignment** (i.e., the assignment remains legally effective even if notice is not given).  
   - This aligns with the query’s focus on an anti-assignment clause where notice is required only for affiliate assignments.  

3. **Contrasts with Assignments to Third Parties** – The clause treats assignments to **non-affiliates (Third Parties)** differently (subsection (b)), requiring stricter conditions (e.g., written assumption of obligations, simultaneous assignment of related agreements). This further emphasizes that the notice requirement applies **only to affiliate assignments**, not third-party transfers.  

### **Key Takeaway for the Query**  
The clause explicitly requires **notice for affiliate assignments** (but not consent) while maintaining stricter restrictions for non-affiliate assignments. This matches the query’s requirement of an anti-assignment provision where notice is mandated only for assignments to affiliates.

query_id: Anti-Assignment clause that requires notice only for assignment to affiliates
clause: Any assignment not in accordance with this Section 11.1 shall be void. Neither this Agreement nor any interest hereunder shall be assignable by a Party without the prior written consent of the other Party, except as follows: (a) such Party may assign its rights and obligations under this Agreement to any of its Affiliates, provided that the assignee shall expressly agree to be bound by such Party's obligations under this Agreement and that such Party shall remain liable for all of its rights and obligations under this Agreement, and (b) either Party may assign its rights and obligations hereunder to a Third Party in connection with a permitted assignment or other permitted transfer of the License Agreement. Each Party shall promptly notify the other Party of any assignment or transfer under the provisions of this Section 11.1.

2. **Exception for Affiliates (Subsection (a))**:  
   - A party may assign its rights/obligations to an **Affiliate** without consent, provided:  
     - The affiliate agrees to be bound by the terms.  
     - The assigning party remains liable.  
   - **Critically, this exception does not explicitly require notice** (though notice may be implied by the final sentence).

3. **Exception for Third-Party Transfers (Subsection (b))**:  
   - Permits assignment to a **Third Party** only if tied to a permitted transfer under the **License Agreement** (a separate contract).  
   - This requires compliance with another agreement, not just notice.

4. **Notice Requirement (Final Sentence)**:  
   - **"Each Party shall promptly notify the other Party of any assignment or transfer under this Section 11.1."**  
   - This applies to **all assignments** under the section, including those to affiliates (subsection (a)) and third parties (subsection (b)).  

### Relevance to the Query:
- The clause **allows affiliate assignments without consent** but still **requires notice** (final sentence).  
- For third-party assignments, additional conditions (e.g., linkage to the License Agreement) apply, going beyond mere notice.  
- Thus, the clause **prioritizes notice for affiliate assignments** while imposing stricter rules for non-affiliate transfers.

3. Other assignments (e.g., to third parties) may have additional conditions (here, tied to the License Agreement).

query_id: Anti-Assignment clause that requires notice only for assignment to affiliates
clause: Any attempted assignment in violation of this section shall be void. This Agreement shall not be assignable by either party unless the assignee expressly assumes in writing the obligations of the assignor hereunder. Network Affiliate may not assign or transfer, by operation of law or otherwise, any of its rights under this Agreement or delegate any of its duties under this Agreement to any third party without NCM's prior written consent, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed.
explanation:
The query asks for an **anti-assignment clause that requires notice only for assignments to affiliates**. The provided clause partially aligns with this requirement but has broader restrictions. Here’s the relevance and analysis:

### **Key Aspects of the Clause:**
1. **General Anti-Assignment Provision**  
   - The clause voids any assignment made in violation of its terms.  
   - It requires **all assignees** (not just affiliates) to assume the assignor’s obligations in writing.  

2. **Specific Restriction on Network Affiliate**  
   - The clause explicitly addresses assignments by a **"Network Affiliate"** (likely an affiliate of one of the parties).  
   - It prohibits the Network Affiliate from assigning rights or delegating duties **without prior written consent** from NCM (the other party).  
   - Consent cannot be "unreasonably withheld," implying a notice-and-approval process for affiliate assignments.  

3. **Does It Fully Match the Query?**  
   - The clause **requires consent (not just notice)** for affiliate assignments, which is stricter than a mere notice requirement.  
   - It also applies the consent requirement **only to the "Network Affiliate"** (not all affiliates of either party).  
   - The general anti-assignment rule applies to **all assignments**, not just those involving affiliates.  

### **Conclusion**  
The clause is **partially relevant** to the query because:  
- It specifically regulates assignments by a defined affiliate (Network Affiliate) and requires consent (not just notice).  
- However, it does not impose a **notice-only** requirement for affiliates broadly; instead, it mandates **consent** for a specific affiliate.  

If the goal is a clause where **any affiliate assignment merely requires notice** (not consent), this clause would need modification to:  
1. Remove the consent requirement for affiliates.  
2. Replace it with a notice obligation (e.g., "Party A must provide written notice to Party B before assigning to an affiliate").  
3. Clarify whether the notice applies to all affiliates or only certain categories.  

Would you like a revised clause tailored to the query?

query_id: Revenue/Profit Sharing
clause: The parties will share equally all revenue from the listing of paper or local coupons in the Co-Branded Application. For Untargeted Offers that appear both on the Co-Branded Application and elsewhere on the Excite Network, revenue attributable to placement on the Co-Branded Application shall be calculated based on the price to be established as set forth in Section 2.a of this Exhibit, and the parties will share equally such revenue. The parties will share equally all revenue from the sale of Untargeted Offers sold for display in the Co-Branded Application. Revenue generated by the parties from such activities shall not be shared but rather shall be retained by the respective party to whom the Sponsorship tile(s) are allocated. This equal division of revenue shall not extend to any placement of Untargeted Offers outside the Co-Branded Application. Excite@Home and e-centives shall share equally all net revenue from such offers, defined as gross revenue minus third-party serving costs, which shall not exceed $0.01 per email piece delivered. Excite@Home will pay e-centives *****% of net revenue (gross revenue less $***** purchase price and cost of sales not to exceed *****% of gross revenues) generated from sales of the e-centives packages. In the event that Excite@Home delivers more than ***** Payment-Eligible General Program Member User Data records and/or more than ***** Payment-Eligible Qualified Program Member User Data records during the Term of the Agreement, e-centives will pay Excite@Home, on a quarterly basis, *****% of net revenue (gross revenue less direct third party commissions) generated from the delivery of offers to any such excess Program Members.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **Revenue/Profit Sharing** as it outlines the specific terms under which the parties (Excite@Home and e-centives) will share revenue generated from various activities related to the Co-Branded Application and other offerings. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

### Key Revenue/Profit Sharing Provisions:
1. **Equal Revenue Sharing for Certain Activities**  
   - The parties will share **equally** all revenue from:  
     - Listing paper or local coupons in the Co-Branded Application.  
     - **Untargeted Offers** displayed in the Co-Branded Application (revenue calculated per Section 2.a).  
     - Sales of Untargeted Offers specifically for the Co-Branded Application.  

2. **Exclusions from Equal Sharing**  
   - Revenue from **Sponsorship tiles** is retained by the party to whom they are allocated (no sharing).  
   - Revenue from Untargeted Offers placed **outside** the Co-Branded Application is not subject to equal sharing.  

3. **Net Revenue Sharing for Specific Offers**  
   - For Untargeted Offers, net revenue (gross revenue minus third-party serving costs, capped at $0.01 per email) is shared equally.  
   - Excite@Home pays e-centives a **percentage of net revenue** (after deducting purchase price and capped sales costs) from sales of e-centives packages.  

4. **Adjustments for Excess Deliveries**  
   - If Excite@Home delivers more than a threshold of user data records, e-centives pays Excite@Home a **percentage of net revenue** (after deducting third-party commissions) from offers sent to those excess users.  

### Relevance to the Query:  
This clause directly addresses **how revenue and profits are divided** between the parties, covering:  
- **What is shared equally**: Certain Co-Branded Application revenues.  
- **What is excluded**: Sponsorship tiles and external placements.  
- **How net revenue is calculated**: Deductions for costs/commissions before sharing.  
- **Variable sharing terms**: Percentage-based splits for specific scenarios (e.g., e-centives packages, excess user data).  

It ensures transparency and fairness in revenue allocation while accounting for operational costs and performance thresholds. The redacted percentages (*****) suggest confidential terms, but the structure of sharing is clearly defined.

query_id: Revenue/Profit Sharing
clause: Commencing with the calendar quarter beginning on April 1, 2006 and for each calendar quarter thereafter during the Term, Network shall pay to Affiliate the Affiliate Transactional Share. In consideration of the terms and conditions set forth herein, Network shall pay Affiliate (i) the Affiliate Advertising Share, and (ii) the Affiliate Transactional Share, each as provided in Exhibit D. Except for the Local Advertising and advertising broadcast in Local Programming, Network shall have the exclusive right and authority to sell all of the advertising on the Service and shall share a portion of Network's Advertising Revenue generated from such sales with Affiliate in accordance with the terms of this Agreement. For purposes hereof, the "Affiliate Transactional Share" means fifteen percent (15%) of Network's Transactional Revenue for the pertinent calendar quarter. Commencing with the calendar quarter beginning on April 1, 2006 and for each calendar quarter thereafter during the Term, Network shall pay to Affiliate the Affiliate Advertising Share. For purposes hereof, the "Affiliate Advertising Share" shall be determined by multiplying fifteen percent (15%) of Network's Advertising Revenue for such calendar quarter by a fraction, the numerator of which is the total number of Digital Cable Subscriber Households in the DMA(s) of the Station(s) transmitting the Service pursuant to this Agreement, and the denominator of which is the total number of Digital Cable Subscriber Households in all of the DMAs in which Network has a broadcast television station affiliate that is transmitting the Service.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the query about **Revenue/Profit Sharing** as it outlines the specific terms under which revenue and profits are shared between the **Network** and the **Affiliate**. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

1. **Types of Revenue Sharing**  
   - The clause specifies two forms of revenue sharing:  
     - **Affiliate Transactional Share**: 15% of the Network's **Transactional Revenue** (e.g., revenue from transactions like pay-per-view, subscriptions, or other user-paid services).  
     - **Affiliate Advertising Share**: A portion (15%) of the Network's **Advertising Revenue**, adjusted by a formula based on the Affiliate's subscriber reach in their designated market area (DMA).  

2. **Payment Timing**  
   - Payments begin with the calendar quarter starting **April 1, 2006**, and continue quarterly for the duration of the agreement ("the Term").  

3. **Exclusivity and Scope**  
   - The Network retains **exclusive rights** to sell advertising on the Service (except for local advertising), but shares a defined portion of advertising revenue with the Affiliate.  
   - The Affiliate's share of advertising revenue is **proportional** to their subscriber base relative to the Network's total subscriber footprint.  

4. **Key Definitions**  
   - **Affiliate Transactional Share**: Fixed 15% of transactional revenue.  
   - **Affiliate Advertising Share**: 15% of advertising revenue, weighted by the Affiliate's DMA subscriber share.  

### Why This Matters for the Query  
The clause answers how revenue/profits are split:  
- **Transactional Revenue**: Straight 15% cut to the Affiliate.  
- **Advertising Revenue**: 15% of total ad revenue, scaled by the Affiliate's market penetration.  
- **Transparency**: Clear formulas and timing ensure predictability for both parties.  

This structure ensures the Affiliate is compensated fairly based on their contribution to the Network's revenue streams.

clause: Any one or more of the following events shall constitute a "Maintenance Event of Default" under this Agreement:<omitted>(d) if Investor shall, at any time, fail to have committed capital in an aggregate minimum amount equal to $5,000,000 less the sum of all Required Capital Contributions (if any) actually made by the Investor during the term of this Agreement, as determined based on the most recent information made available by the Investor to the Agent pursuant to Section 20 below; The Investor agrees to deliver to the Agent, from time to time, promptly following Agent's request therefor, a sworn affidavit or other evidence reasonably acceptable to the Agent substantiating that the Investor has committed capital in an aggregate minimum amount equal to $5,000,000 less the sum of all Required Capital Contributions (if any) actually made by the Investor during the term of this Agreement.

2. **Consequence of Failure (Event of Default)**:  
   If the Investor fails to meet this minimum commitment, it constitutes a **"Maintenance Event of Default"**, which could trigger remedies or penalties under the agreement (e.g., termination, forfeiture of rights, or other enforcement actions).

3. **Verification Mechanism**:

In summary, this clause defines and enforces the **minimum financial commitment** expected from the Investor, with mechanisms to ensure compliance and consequences for non-compliance.

query_id: IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer
clause: Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Party may transfer or assign its rights under this IP Agreement in connection with a merger, acquisition or sale of all or substantially all of its assets, on condition that it provides the <omitted> other Party with notice of the transfer or assignment.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the **IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer** query because it addresses the conditions under which a party can transfer or assign its intellectual property (IP) rights under the agreement. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

1. **Scope of Transfer/Assignment**:  
   The clause permits a party to transfer or assign its IP rights **only** in specific corporate scenarios:  
   - A **merger** (combining with another entity).  
   - An **acquisition** (being bought by another entity).  
   - A **sale of all or substantially all assets** (liquidating or restructuring the business).  

   This ensures IP rights cannot be arbitrarily transferred outside these major structural changes.

2. **Condition for Transfer**:  
   The transferring party must **notify the other party** (the counterparty to the agreement) of the assignment or transfer. This maintains transparency and allows the non-transferring party to track ownership changes affecting their rights or obligations.

3. **Alignment with IP Ownership Concerns**:  
   The clause balances flexibility (allowing IP transfers in legitimate business reorganizations) with control (requiring notice to prevent undisclosed assignments). It safeguards both parties by:  
   - Preventing unauthorized transfers that could disrupt IP ownership.  
   - Ensuring continuity of rights even after corporate changes.  

In summary, this clause directly answers the query by defining **when and how IP ownership can be reassigned**, which is critical for risk management and contractual clarity in IP agreements.

query_id: IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer
clause: If and to the extent that, as a matter of Law in any jurisdiction, ownership, title, or any rights or interest in or to any of the Assigned IP cannot be assigned as provided in Section 2.1(b)(i), (A) the Seller irrevocably agrees to (and shall cause the other Seller Parties to) assign and transfer, and the Seller hereby assigns and transfers (and shall cause the other Seller Parties to assign and transfer) to the Purchaser Assignees all rights (including all economic and commercialization rights) that can be assigned pursuant to Section 2.1(b)(i) to the fullest extent permissible, and (B) the Seller hereby grants to the Purchaser Assignees, and hereby agrees to cause the other Seller Parties to grant to the Purchaser Assignees, an unlimited, exclusive, irrevocable, assignable, transferable, sublicenseable, worldwide, perpetual, royalty-free, fully-paid up license to use, exploit, and commercialize in any manner now known or in the future discovered and for whatever purpose, any and all rights to Assigned IP that cannot be assigned as contemplated by Section 2.1(b)(i).
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer** because it addresses a critical scenario where full legal ownership of intellectual property (IP) cannot be transferred due to jurisdictional or other legal constraints. Here’s how it aligns with the query:

### Key Relevance:
1. **Fallback Mechanism for IP Transfer**  
   - The clause anticipates situations where certain IP rights (the "Assigned IP") cannot be legally assigned outright under the laws of a jurisdiction (e.g., moral rights, certain statutory rights, or local IP restrictions).  
   - It ensures the **Purchaser Assignees** still obtain maximum possible control over the IP by:  
     - **Assigning transferable rights** (economic/commercialization rights) to the fullest extent permissible (Part A).  
     - **Granting a comprehensive license** for any non-assignable rights (Part B).  

2. **Comprehensive License as a Backup**  
   - If ownership cannot be transferred, the Seller grants an **irrevocable, exclusive, perpetual, and royalty-free license** covering all residual rights (e.g., use, exploitation, commercialization).  
   - The license terms are broad (global, sublicensable, etc.) to mimic ownership as closely as possible.  

3. **Seller Obligations**  
   - The Seller commits to binding **itself and related parties** ("Seller Parties") to these terms, ensuring no gaps in the transfer/license chain.  

### Why It Matters for the Query:  
This clause ensures **no IP rights remain with the Seller unintentionally**, addressing legal uncertainties while maximizing the Purchaser’s control. It is a standard but critical provision in IP assignment agreements to mitigate jurisdictional risks and ensure enforceability.  

**Practical Impact**: Even if the law prevents an outright assignment, the Purchaser retains all practical benefits of ownership through the license, safeguarding commercialization and future transfers.  

Would you like any specific terms (e.g., "irrevocable," "perpetual") clarified further?

query_id: IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer
clause: This IP Agreement will be binding upon and inure to the benefit of the Parties hereto and their respective successors and permitted assigns, but will not be assignable or delegable by any Party without the prior written consent of the other Party. Any attempted transfer in contravention of this Section 9.3 shall be null and void.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer** because it governs the conditions under which the rights and obligations under the IP Agreement can be transferred to another party. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

1. **Binding Effect on Successors and Assigns**  
   - The clause ensures that the agreement remains enforceable not just between the original parties but also their **successors (e.g., heirs, merged entities)** and **permitted assigns (approved transferees)**. This is critical for IP ownership continuity, especially in cases like corporate reorganizations or acquisitions.

2. **Restriction on Unauthorized Assignment/Delegation**  
   - A party cannot **assign (transfer rights)** or **delegate (transfer obligations)** under the agreement without the **prior written consent** of the other party. This protects both parties from unwanted third-party involvement in IP ownership or control.

3. **Consequence of Violation**  
   - Any attempted transfer without consent is declared **"null and void"**, meaning it has no legal effect. This safeguards against unauthorized transfers of IP rights, ensuring compliance with the agreed terms.

### Why It Matters for IP Ownership Transfer:  
- **Control Over IP Rights**: Prevents one party from unilaterally transferring IP to a competitor or unrelated entity.  
- **Legal Certainty**: Ensures any valid transfer requires mutual agreement, reducing disputes over ownership.  
- **Enforceability**: Reinforces that breaches of this clause will not be recognized, protecting the original parties' interests.  

In summary, this clause directly addresses the **conditions and limitations** for transferring IP ownership or rights under the agreement, making it a key provision for IP-related contracts.

query_id: IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer
clause: If a Seller Party assigns or transfers any Licensed IP, the Seller shall (or shall cause the applicable Seller Party to) expressly condition such assignment or transfer on the express acknowledgement and agreement of the assignee or transferee that all such Licensed IP is bound by the license grants set forth herein. If Purchaser or a Purchaser Assignee assigns or transfers any Intellectual Property licensed to the Seller Parties pursuant to Section 2.1(c) or Section 2.1(d), the Purchaser shall (or shall cause the applicable Purchaser Assignee to) expressly condition such assignment or transfer on the express acknowledgement and agreement of the assignee or transferee that all such Intellectual Property is bound by such license grants. Neither party may assign (whether by operation of law or otherwise) this IP Agreement, or any of its licenses, rights, privileges or obligations hereunder, without the prior written consent of the other party, and any such attempted assignment shall be void; provided, however, that, following the Initial Closing Date, without any such prior written consent but upon prior written notice to the other party, each party may assign this IP Agreement to: (i) an Affiliate; (ii) a lender for collateral security; (iii) a Person that succeeds to all or substantially all of its business or assets to which this IP Agreement relates in connection with a merger or sale of all or substantially all of its assets to which this IP Agreement relates; or (iv) corporate reorganization of the party in which the ultimate ownership of the party immediately prior to such reorganization is the same as the ultimate ownership of the party immediately after such reorganization.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer** because it establishes clear rules and conditions governing how intellectual property (IP) can be assigned or transferred between the parties (Seller Party and Purchaser/Purchaser Assignee) and third parties. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

### 1. **Conditional Assignment/Transfer of Licensed IP**  
   - If the **Seller Party** assigns or transfers any **Licensed IP**, the assignee/transferee must explicitly acknowledge that the IP remains subject to the license grants in the agreement.  
   - Similarly, if the **Purchaser** assigns or transfers **IP licensed to the Seller Parties**, the new owner must agree that the Seller Parties’ license rights continue.  
   - **Relevance**: Ensures that license rights survive any transfer, protecting both parties’ interests.

### 2. **Restrictions on Assignment of the Agreement**  
   - Neither party can assign the **entire IP Agreement** or any of its rights/obligations without the other party’s **prior written consent** (otherwise, the assignment is void).  
   - **Relevance**: Prevents unauthorized transfers that could disrupt the contractual balance.

### 3. **Permitted Assignments Without Consent**  
   - After the **Initial Closing Date**, assignments are allowed **without consent but with prior notice** in specific cases, such as:  
     - Transfers to **Affiliates** (e.g., subsidiaries).  
     - **Lenders** (for collateral security).  
     - **Successors** in mergers/sales of substantially all assets.  
     - **Corporate reorganizations** (if ultimate ownership remains unchanged).  
   - **Relevance**: Provides flexibility for legitimate business restructuring while ensuring transparency.

### **Key Takeaways for the Query**  
- The clause ensures that **IP licenses persist** even after assignment/transfer, safeguarding both parties’ rights.  
- It **restricts arbitrary assignments** but allows structured exceptions (e.g., mergers, security interests).  
- It balances **control** (consent requirements) with **practicality** (permitted transfers for business needs).  

This directly addresses concerns about **IP ownership continuity and licensing obligations** during transfers, which is central to the query.

query_id: IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer
clause: To the extent that the Company IP does not vest automatically in the Company the Executive hereby assigns all right, title and interest in the Company IP to the Company with full title guarantee by way of a present assignment of all future rights and shall otherwise hold them on trust for the Company.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the query about **IP Ownership Assignment or Transfer** as it ensures that all intellectual property (IP) created by the Executive in connection with their work for the Company is legally transferred to the Company, even if it does not automatically vest in the Company by default. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

1. **Automatic Vesting Fallback**:  
   - Some IP rights (e.g., copyright in certain jurisdictions) may automatically belong to the creator (the Executive) unless otherwise agreed. This clause addresses situations where IP does **not** automatically vest in the Company.

2. **Explicit Assignment**:  
   - The Executive **assigns all right, title, and interest** in the Company IP to the Company, ensuring a clear transfer of ownership. This includes future rights (e.g., IP not yet created at the time of signing).

3. **Full Title Guarantee**:  
   - The assignment is made with "full title guarantee," meaning the Executive warrants they have the legal right to transfer the IP and that it is free from undisclosed encumbrances.

4. **Trust Mechanism**:  
   - If the IP does not immediately transfer (e.g., due to jurisdictional requirements), the Executive agrees to **hold it on trust** for the Company, preventing any claim of personal ownership.

### Why This Matters for the Query:  
- **Clarity**: Ensures no ambiguity about IP ownership, protecting the Company’s proprietary assets.  
- **Future-Proofing**: Covers both existing and future IP, avoiding gaps in ownership.  
- **Enforceability**: The combination of assignment and trust provisions strengthens the Company’s legal position globally, especially in jurisdictions where automatic vesting may not apply.  

This clause is a robust safeguard for the Company’s IP rights, addressing potential loopholes in ownership transfer.

query_id: Joint IP Ownership
clause: In the event that any Development IP is jointly invented by the Parties in accordance with applicable intellectual property laws, then the ownership of such Development IP that has been jointly invented shall be co-owned by the Parties in accordance with such applicable intellectual property laws; provided, however, that neither Party shall have any duty or obligation to account to the other for any use or exploitation of such jointly invented Development IP and as between the Parties, each Party shall be entitled to retain any and all benefit, financial or otherwise, derived by such Party from such jointly invented Development IP.
explanation:
This clause directly addresses the query on **Joint IP Ownership** by outlining the rights and obligations of the parties when intellectual property (IP) is jointly invented during the course of their collaboration. Here’s how it aligns with the query:

1. **Definition of Joint Ownership**:  
   The clause confirms that if Development IP is jointly invented under applicable IP laws, the parties will **co-own** it. This establishes the legal framework for shared ownership, which is central to the query.

2. **No Duty to Account**:  
   It clarifies that neither party is required to **account to the other** (e.g., share profits or royalties) for their use or commercialization of the jointly owned IP. This is a critical aspect of joint ownership, as it removes potential disputes over financial obligations.

3. **Unrestricted Exploitation Rights**:  
   Each party retains the right to **freely use and benefit** from the jointly invented IP without owing the other party compensation. This is a permissive approach that avoids restrictions on commercialization, which is often a key concern in joint IP arrangements.

4. **Alignment with Applicable IP Laws**:  
   The clause defers to **local intellectual property laws** to determine joint inventorship and ownership, ensuring compliance with jurisdictional requirements.  

### **Relevance to the Query**  
The query seeks clarity on how joint IP ownership is handled, and this clause provides a clear answer:  
- Co-ownership is automatic for jointly invented IP.  
- No financial or reporting obligations exist between parties.  
- Each party can independently exploit the IP for its own benefit.  

This structure avoids conflicts over licensing or revenue-sharing while ensuring both parties retain full rights to the jointly owned IP. However, it may not suit collaborations where shared profits or control are desired (e.g., in revenue-generating partnerships).  

Would you like suggestions to modify this clause for a different outcome (e.g., profit-sharing or restrictions on use)?

query_id: Joint IP Ownership
clause: All right, title and interest in and to the Improved Conformis Background IP and KIB Product IP ("Joint IP") shall be owned jointly by the Parties.<omitted>Each Party to whom ownership is to vest in Joint IP by operation of law or by assignment by its employees or Agents agrees to assign and hereby assigns to the other Party an undivided one-half right, title and interest in and to all Joint IP; and to facilitate such assignment, the Party possessing such ownership agrees (i) to regularly ensure that its employees and consultants timely make any appropriate assignments to it; and (ii) at the other Party's reasonable request, to execute and have its employees and consultants execute, as necessary, all assignments and any other documentation to perfect the undivided one-half right, title and interest in and to the other Party of such Joint IP.<omitted>Subject to the limitations set forth in this Agreement, the Joint IP may be used freely by either Party or its Affiliates and licensed to Third Parties by Conformis and its Affiliates, on the one hand, outside of the Buyer Field or by Stryker and its Affiliates, on the other hand, within the Buyer Field, in each case, without the consent of, or duty to account to or notify, the other Party, but, except with respect to external licenses of the Improved Conformis Background IP by Conformis or its Affiliates to Third Parties, any external Third Party license shall be governed in accordance with the last sentence of Section 4.3(c) of the APA.
explanation:
This clause addresses **Joint IP Ownership** by establishing the framework for how intellectual property ("Joint IP") created or improved under the agreement is owned, assigned, and exploited by the parties (Conformis and Stryker). Here’s how it relates to the query:  

1. **Ownership Structure**:  
   - The clause confirms that Joint IP (defined as "Improved Conformis Background IP" and "KIB Product IP") is **jointly owned** by both parties, with each holding an **undivided one-half interest**.  
   - It mandates that each party ensures its employees/agents assign their rights to enable this joint ownership (e.g., through assignments or documentation).  

2. **Assignment Obligations**:  
   - Parties must proactively secure assignments from their employees/consultants to vest ownership in Joint IP.  
   - They must also cooperate to **perfect the other party’s 50% interest** (e.g., by executing additional documents if requested).  

3. **Usage and Licensing Rights**:  
   - **No restrictions**: Either party (or its affiliates) may freely use the Joint IP without consent or accounting to the other.  
   - **Licensing to third parties**:  
     - **Conformis** may license Joint IP **outside the "Buyer Field"** (a defined scope, likely tied to Stryker’s exclusive rights).  
     - **Stryker** may license Joint IP **within the "Buyer Field"** (its designated area of use).  
   - External licenses (except for Conformis’ licenses of Improved Background IP) must comply with **Section 4.3(c)** of the APA (likely addressing revenue sharing or other terms).  

### **Relevance to the Query**  
This clause comprehensively governs:  
- How Joint IP is **owned** (50/50 split).  
- How ownership is **secured** (assignments/paperwork).  
- How parties may **exploit** the IP (usage/licensing rights).  
- Any **limitations** (e.g., field-specific licensing, compliance with other agreement sections).  

It ensures clarity on rights and obligations while allowing flexibility for commercialization within defined boundaries.  

Would you like further analysis on specific subclauses (e.g., assignment mechanics, licensing conditions)?

query_id: Joint IP Ownership
clause: Investor shall own all right, title and interest in any Improvement made jointly by Company and Investor ("Joint Improvements") during the term of this IP Agreement, and Company agrees to and hereby does assign to Investor any right, title and interest it may otherwise have in any Joint Improvement.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the query about **Joint IP Ownership** as it defines the ownership rights and assignment obligations concerning improvements made collaboratively by the Company and the Investor ("Joint Improvements"). Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

1. **Ownership Allocation**:  
   The clause states that the **Investor** will own **all right, title, and interest** in any Joint Improvement, overriding any default joint ownership principles that might otherwise apply (e.g., equal shares under common law). This ensures the Investor has exclusive control over the IP.

2. **Assignment Obligation**:  
   The Company **explicitly assigns** its potential rights in Joint Improvements to the Investor, eliminating ambiguity or future disputes over ownership. This is a proactive measure to ensure the Investor’s sole ownership is legally enforceable.

3. **Scope of Application**:  
   The clause applies only to improvements made **during the term of the IP Agreement** and those created **jointly** by both parties. It does not address independently developed IP or pre-existing rights.

4. **Implications for the Company**:  
   The Company relinquishes all claims to Joint Improvements, which could limit its ability to use or commercialize them unless otherwise negotiated (e.g., through a license-back provision). This is critical for the Company to understand when entering the agreement.

5. **Investor Protection**:  
   The clause prioritizes the Investor’s interests, ensuring it retains full IP rights to collaborative developments, which is typical in investment agreements where the Investor funds R&D or innovation efforts.

**Why It Matters for the Query**:  
The clause clarifies how joint contributions to IP are treated, avoiding default joint ownership rules that might require profit-sharing or mutual consent for exploitation. It aligns with scenarios where one party (the Investor) seeks to secure IP rights as a return on investment, while the other (the Company) accepts restricted rights in exchange for funding or collaboration.  

**Potential Considerations**:  
- If the Company wishes to retain any rights (e.g., a license), this clause would need modification.  
- The definition of "Improvement" should be reviewed to ensure it covers the intended scope (e.g., whether it includes derivative works or minor modifications).  

In summary, this clause is a **one-sided joint IP ownership provision** favoring the Investor, which is common in venture or R&D agreements but may require balancing terms elsewhere in the contract.

Subject to the limitations set forth in this Agreement, the Joint IP may be used freely by either Party or its Affiliates and licensed to Third Parties by Conformis and its Affiliates, on the one hand, outside of the Buyer Field or by Stryker and its Affiliates, on the other hand, within the Buyer Field, in each case, without the consent of, or duty to account to or notify, the other Party, but, except with respect to external licenses of the Improved Conformis Background IP by Conformis or its Affiliates to Third Parties, any external Third Party license shall be governed in accordance with the last sentence of Section 4.3(c) of the APA.
explanation:
This clause addresses **Joint IP Ownership** by establishing the rights, obligations, and usage permissions for intellectual property ("Joint IP") co-owned by the parties (Conformis and Stryker). Here’s how it aligns with the query:  

1. **Ownership Structure**:  
   - The clause confirms that both parties hold an **undivided one-half interest** in the Joint IP (Improved Conformis Background IP and KIB Product IP).

query_id: Joint IP Ownership
clause: Neither party may assign (whether by operation of law or otherwise) this IP Agreement, or any of its licenses, rights, privileges or obligations hereunder, without the prior written consent of the other party, and any such attempted assignment shall be void; provided, however, that, following the Initial Closing Date, without any such prior written consent but upon prior written notice to the other party, each party may assign this IP Agreement to: (i) an Affiliate; (ii) a lender for collateral security; (iii) a Person that succeeds to all or substantially all of its business or assets to which this IP Agreement relates in connection with a merger or sale of all or substantially all of its assets to which this IP Agreement relates; or (iv) corporate reorganization of the party in which the ultimate ownership of the party immediately prior to such reorganization is the same as the ultimate ownership of the party immediately after such reorganization.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **Joint IP Ownership** because it governs the conditions under which either party can transfer or assign their rights, licenses, or obligations under the IP Agreement to a third party. Here’s how it connects to joint IP ownership:

### Key Relevance to Joint IP Ownership:
1. **Restriction on Unilateral Assignments**  
   - The clause ensures that neither party can unilaterally transfer their rights or obligations under the agreement without the other party’s **prior written consent**. This protects the joint ownership structure by preventing one party from undermining the other’s interests (e.g., by assigning IP rights to a competitor or an untrusted third party).

2. **Exceptions for Permitted Assignments**  
   - While general assignments are restricted, the clause allows certain exceptions (e.g., to affiliates, lenders, or successors in mergers/sales). These exceptions balance flexibility with control, ensuring that joint ownership isn’t disrupted by routine business reorganizations or financing activities.  
   - For example, if one party undergoes a **merger** (iii) or **corporate restructuring** (iv), the IP rights can transfer without consent, provided the ultimate ownership remains consistent. This avoids unnecessary hurdles while preserving the joint ownership framework.

3. **Protection Against Unauthorized Transfers**  
   - Any attempted assignment without compliance (e.g., to a non-affiliate without consent) is deemed **void**, safeguarding the joint owners from unauthorized dilution of their rights.

4. **Notice Requirement**  
   - Even for permitted assignments (like to an affiliate), the assigning party must provide **prior written notice**. This ensures transparency, allowing the other joint owner to monitor changes that might affect their shared IP.

### Why This Matters for Joint IP Ownership:  
Joint ownership requires mutual control over IP to prevent one party from acting in a way that harms the other’s interests. This clause enforces that principle by:  
- **Limiting transfers** unless agreed or under controlled conditions.  
- **Allowing flexibility** for legitimate business needs (e.g., corporate restructuring).  
- **Ensuring accountability** through notice and consent mechanisms.  

In summary, the clause protects the stability and intent of the joint IP arrangement while accommodating practical business scenarios.

query_id: License clause covering affiliates of licensor and/or licensee
clause: For the avoidance of doubt, Licensor also grants to Licensee and its subsidiaries and affiliates a non-exclusive, worldwide royalty-free license for continued use of the Licensed Mark for the production and sale of inventory containing the Licensed Mark applied to such products during the Transition Period as set forth in section 8.2 of the Separation and Distribution Agreement and in Schedule 2 of this Agreement. For avoidance of doubt, to the extent that any of the licenses granted by the terms of this Agreement include any right to sublicense, such right to sublicense shall extend to Licensee's subsidiaries and joint venturers.
explanation:
This clause is directly relevant to the query about **license coverage for affiliates of the licensor and/or licensee** in the following ways:

### 1. **Coverage of Affiliates/Subsidiaries**  
   - The clause explicitly extends the license grant to **Licensee's subsidiaries and affiliates**, ensuring they are covered under the same terms as the Licensee. This avoids ambiguity about whether affiliated entities can use the Licensed Mark.  
   - The phrase *"Licensee and its subsidiaries and affiliates"* makes it clear that the license is not limited to the primary contracting party but includes its corporate group.

### 2. **Sublicensing Rights for Affiliates**  
   - The clause clarifies that if the license includes sublicensing rights, those rights also extend to **subsidiaries and joint venturers** of the Licensee. This ensures that affiliated entities (e.g., joint ventures) can further sublicense the Licensed Mark if permitted under the agreement.  

### 3. **Transition Period Continuity**  
   - The license allows affiliates to continue using the Licensed Mark for **existing inventory** during a defined **Transition Period**, as referenced in another agreement (Section 8.2 of the Separation and Distribution Agreement and Schedule 2). This prevents disruption for affiliated entities post-termination or transition.  

### 4. **Avoidance of Doubt (Clarity)**  
   - The repeated use of *"For the avoidance of doubt"* emphasizes that the parties intended to explicitly include affiliates in the license grant, reducing potential disputes over whether they are covered.  

### **Relevance to Query**  
This clause directly addresses the query by:  
- Confirming that **affiliates of the Licensee** (subsidiaries, joint venturers) are included in the license grant.  
- Ensuring that sublicensing rights (if any) also apply to these affiliates.  
- Providing legal certainty about the scope of permitted use by affiliated entities.  

If the query also sought coverage for **Licensor's affiliates**, this clause does not explicitly mention them—it focuses only on the Licensee's affiliates. A reciprocal clause might be needed if the Licensor's affiliates are intended to have obligations or rights under the agreement.
