clause:
7. Indemnification. a. A claim that a Party (referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnifying Party") is required to defend and indemnify the other Party (referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnified Party") under this Agreement is referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnified Claim". Defense and indemnification under this Section will include, without limitation, (1) paying or reimbursing the actual, reasonable, substantiated out-of-pocket expenses incurred in connection with the investigation, defense and settlement of any civil, criminal or administrative action, suit, arbitration, mediation, hearing, audit, investigation or other proceeding threatened or commenced against an Indemnified Party on an Indemnified Claim (e.g., fees and expenses of attorneys, accountants, auditors, investigators, consulting experts, testifying experts and other consultants; fees and expenses of an arbitrator or mediator; filing fees and costs imposed by any court, administrative agency or other tribunal; etc.), and (2) satisfying any judgment, award, order, lien, levy, fine, penalty or other sanction imposed against an Indemnified Party on an Indemnified Claim. b. Seller will defend and indemnify Buyer against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Seller, including, without limitation, any product supplied by Seller which fails to conform to the representations and warranties in this Agreement; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Seller in the design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery of any product sold by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Seller under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, packaging, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement (except to the extent that the infringement is based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license terms in supplying the product); (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by a governmental authority on Buyer to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Seller of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Seller has agreed to defend and indemnify Buyer against under a Purchase Schedule. c. Buyer will defend and indemnify Seller against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Buyer; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Buyer in the purchase, storage, repackaging, resale or delivery of any product purchased from Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Buyer under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement to the extent based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license term in supplying the product; (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by governmental authority on Seller to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Buyer of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Buyer has agreed to defend and indemnify Seller against under a Purchase Schedule. d. As a condition of receiving defense and indemnification under this Section for an Indemnified Claim, the Indemnified Party must: (1) notify and tender the defense of an Indemnified Claim to the Indemnifying Party promptly after the Indemnified Party learns of the Indemnified Claim; and
(2) provide information and cooperation reasonably requested by the Indemnifying Party in the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. An Indemnifying Party will reimburse the Indemnified Party of any reasonable, actual, substantiated out-of-pocket expense incurred in providing the requested information or cooperation. e. If the Indemnifying Party accepts the tender of defense of an Indemnified Claim, with or without reservation, the Indemnifying Party will: (1) promptly notify the Indemnified Party of the acceptance of the tender of defense of the Indemnified Claim. (2) control the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim, including, without limitation, the selection of licensed, qualified and reputable attorneys and expert witnesses and all decisions over settlement and litigation strategy. The Indemnifying Party must act in good faith in exercising control over the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. (3) Provide information reasonably requested by the Indemnified Party regarding the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim f. An Indemnifying Party, acting in good faith, may settle an Indemnified Claim for which it is responsible under this Agreement involving infringement on the intellectual property of a third-party by: (1) obtaining a license from the third-party allowing the required use of its intellectual property; (2) modifying a product, equipment or process in a manner which avoids infringing on the intellectual property of the third-party; or (3) voluntarily withdrawing the infringing product from the market and either refunding the amount paid by the Indemnified Party for the infringing product or replacing the infringing product with a non-infringing product. g. The Parties may disagree on whether a claim is an Indemnified Claim under this Agreement, which Party should be considered the Indemnifying Party and Indemnified Party for an Indemnified Claim or whether each Party is partially liable for an Indemnified Claim and how liability for such an Indemnified Claim should be allocated between them. In these and other circumstances in which an actual or potential conflict of interest exists or arises between the Parties with regards to an alleged or agreed upon Indemnified Claim that would preclude their joint representation by a single defense counsel, the Parties will endeavor in good faith to attempt to resolve the conflict. If the Parties are able to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, the Parties will memorialize the agreed upon resolution in a written joint defense agreement signed by officers of each Party and their joint defense counsel. If the Parties are unable to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, each Party may independently and separately investigate, defend, settle and satisfy the claim subject to their right to pursue payment or reimbursement for costs incurred in doing so from the other Party as provided in this Agreement.
explanation:
The query asks about **"indemnity of broad-based claims"**, which generally refers to indemnification obligations covering a wide range of potential claims, including third-party claims, regulatory actions, intellectual property disputes, and other liabilities. The provided **Indemnification Clause (Section 7)** is highly relevant to this query because it establishes a comprehensive framework for indemnification between the parties (Seller and Buyer), addressing multiple categories of claims that could arise. Here’s how the clause aligns with the query:

### **1. Scope of Broad-Based Claims Covered**  
The clause explicitly covers a wide array of indemnifiable claims, including:  
- **Third-party claims** (e.g., personal injury, property damage, negligence, or breach of contract) (Sections 7.b.1–2, 7.c.1–2).  
- **Intellectual property infringement claims** (Sections 7.b.3, 7.c.3).  
- **Regulatory fines/penalties** imposed by governmental authorities (Sections 7.b.4, 7.c.4).  
- **Other agreed-upon matters** under a Purchase Schedule (Sections 7.b.5, 7.c.5).  

This breadth ensures that the indemnification obligations are **not narrowly limited** but instead encompass **diverse risks**, making it "broad-based."

### **2. Defense and Indemnification Process**  
The clause details:  
- **What is covered**: Legal fees, expert costs, settlements, judgments, and other expenses (Section 7.a).  
- **Procedural requirements**: Prompt notice, tender of defense, and cooperation (Section 7.d).  
- **Control of defense**: The Indemnifying Party manages the claim (Section 7.e).  
- **Settlement options**: For IP claims, the Indemnifying Party can resolve disputes via licensing, product modification, or withdrawal (Section 7.f).  

This structured approach ensures that **both parties understand their rights and obligations** when handling broad-based claims.

### **3. Conflict Resolution for Disputed Claims**  
If the parties disagree on:  
- Whether a claim qualifies for indemnification,  
- Which party is responsible, or  
- How liability should be allocated,  

the clause provides a **good-faith negotiation process** (Section 7.g) and allows for separate defense if conflicts persist. This flexibility is crucial for **managing complex or overlapping claims**.

### **Conclusion**  
This indemnification clause is **highly relevant to broad-based claims** because:  
1. It **covers a wide variety of potential liabilities** (tort, contract, IP, regulatory).  
2. It **clearly defines procedures** for defense, reimbursement, and settlement.  
3. It **addresses disputes** over responsibility, ensuring enforceability.  

Thus, it serves as a **robust mechanism** for allocating risk between the parties in a manner that anticipates diverse and unpredictable claims.  

Would you like any specific aspect analyzed further?

- While the clause does not directly address indemnification, the inclusion of affiliates in the grant of rights implies they would likely be included in indemnification protections or liabilities unless explicitly excluded elsewhere.

query_id: Indemnified party includes affiliates
clause: Section 9.1 Indemnification. Subject to the limitations set forth in this Article IX, each Party (the "Indemnifying Party") agrees to indemnify, defend and hold harmless the other Party and its Affiliates and its and their respective directors, officers, employees, agents, representatives, successors and permitted assigns (collectively, the "Indemnified Parties") from and against all Losses imposed upon or incurred by an Indemnified Party to the extent arising out of or resulting from the Indemnifying Party's or its Affiliates' material breach of this Agreement, except to the extent that such Losses are primarily caused by the Indemnified Party.
explanation:
The query asks whether the **"Indemnified Party" includes affiliates**, and the provided clause explicitly confirms this. Here’s the relevance:

1. **Definition of "Indemnified Parties"**:  
   The clause defines the **"Indemnified Parties"** broadly to include:  
   - The **other Party** (i.e., the non-breaching party to the agreement),  
   - Its **Affiliates**, and  
   - Its and their **directors, officers, employees, agents, etc.**  

   This means affiliates of the non-breaching party are expressly included as beneficiaries of the indemnification protection.

2. **Scope of Protection**:  
   The indemnification covers **Losses** arising from the Indemnifying Party’s (or its Affiliates’) **material breach of the Agreement**, unless the Losses are primarily caused by the Indemnified Party.  
   - Affiliates of the protected Party are shielded from liability stemming from the counterparty’s breach.  

3. **Alignment with Query**:  
   The clause directly addresses the query by clarifying that affiliates are **expressly included** in the definition of "Indemnified Parties" and are therefore entitled to indemnification under the terms outlined.  

### Key Takeaway:  
The clause explicitly extends indemnification rights to **affiliates of the non-breaching party**, ensuring they are protected against losses caused by the other party’s material breach. This is a common provision to safeguard corporate groups and their stakeholders.

explanation:
The query asks whether the **"Indemnified Party" includes affiliates**, and the provided clause explicitly confirms that it does. Here’s how the clause addresses the query:

### Key Points from the Clause:
1. **Definition of "Indemnified Party" and Affiliates**  
   - Section 7.2 states that the **"Indemnified Party" includes its Affiliates** (along with their employees, directors, and representatives).  
   - The indemnity obligation covers claims, costs, losses, etc., arising from third-party claims (as defined under "Claim") against both the Indemnified Party **and its Affiliates**.

2. **Scope of Indemnification**  
   - The Indemnifying Party must defend and indemnify not only the other Party but also its Affiliates (e.g., subsidiaries or related entities) against third-party claims.  
   - This is reinforced by the phrase:  
     > *"hold harmless the other Party (the 'Indemnified Party') **and its Affiliates**... from and against any and all claims..."*  

3. **Exclusion of Affiliate Claims**  
   - The definition of "Claim" explicitly excludes claims brought by **Affiliates of either Party** (i.e., disputes between the Parties' own Affiliates are not covered by indemnity).  
   - This clarifies that indemnification applies only to **external third-party claims**, not internal disputes.

4. **Confirmation in Damages Clause**  
   - Section 8.2 further supports this by referencing indemnification for third-party judgments, implying Affiliates are protected under the same umbrella as the Indemnified Party.

### Relevance to the Query:  
The clause **explicitly includes Affiliates** as part of the "Indemnified Party," ensuring they are protected under the indemnity provisions. However, claims **between Affiliates of the Parties** are excluded from the definition of "Claim," meaning the indemnity does not cover internal disputes.  

In summary:  
- **Yes**, the Indemnified Party includes its Affiliates for third-party claims.  
- **No**, Affiliates cannot bring indemnifiable claims against each other.  

This balances broad protection for external risks while limiting liability for internal conflicts.

clause: Notwithstanding the foregoing, no rights, obligations or liabilities hereunder shall be assignable by a Party without prior written consent of all of the other Parties; provided, however, that a Party shall not unreasonably withhold its consent to the assignment of rights and obligations by the other Parties to its Affiliate if that Affiliate's performance has been guaranteed satisfactorily in form and substance by the assigning Party.
explanation:
The query asks whether the **"indemnified party includes affiliates"** in the context of the given clause. Here’s how the clause is relevant to the query:

1. **Affiliates as Potential Assignees**:  
   The clause explicitly allows a Party to assign its rights and obligations to an **Affiliate**, provided:  
   - The other Party consents (not unreasonably withheld).  
   - The assigning Party guarantees the Affiliate’s performance.  

   This implies that **Affiliates can step into the shoes of the original Party** under the contract, including assuming rights (such as indemnification) and obligations.

2. **Indemnified Party Implications**:  
   If an Affiliate becomes an assignee under this clause, it would logically inherit the same contractual protections as the original Party, including the right to be **indemnified** (if the contract includes indemnification provisions).  
   - For example, if Party A assigns its rights to Affiliate B, and the contract entitles the "Party" to indemnification, Affiliate B would now qualify as the "indemnified party" by virtue of the assignment.  

3. **Limitation on Scope**:  
   The clause does not automatically extend rights to all Affiliates universally—only to those that are **valid assignees** under the terms (i.e., with consent and a performance guarantee). Thus, affiliates are included as indemnified parties **only if they meet these conditions**.  

### Key Takeaway:  
The clause supports the idea that **affiliates can be indemnified parties**, but only if they are properly assigned rights under the contract and meet the specified requirements (consent + guarantee). It does not grant blanket coverage to all affiliates unless they are formally brought into the agreement via assignment.  

If the contract has a separate definition of "indemnified party" that explicitly includes affiliates, this clause would further reinforce that possibility by allowing affiliates to become contractual parties through assignment.

explanation:
This indemnification clause is highly relevant to the query about **"first party indemnification of specified claims"** because it outlines the scope, conditions, and limitations under which one party (the **Indemnifying Party**) must defend and compensate the other party (the **Indemnified Party**) for certain third-party claims. Here’s a breakdown of its relevance:

### 1. **Definition of "Claim"**  
   - The clause defines **"Claim"** broadly to include any third-party legal action (excluding claims by affiliates), which sets the boundary for what triggers indemnification. This ensures clarity about the types of disputes covered.

### 2. **Specified Claims Triggering Indemnification**  
   The Indemnifying Party must indemnify the other party for claims arising from:  
   - **Operation/content of their own site** (unless caused by the Indemnified Party’s requirements).  
   - **Products/services offered through their site** (with exceptions for the Indemnified Party’s products).  
   - **Breach of representations/warranties** (Section 7.1) or regulatory compliance (Section 4.4, specific to one party).  
   - **Infringement of intellectual property rights** by materials provided by the Indemnifying Party.  

   These are the **"specified claims"** the query refers to—clearly enumerated scenarios where indemnification applies.

### 3. **First-Party Obligations**  
   - The clause assigns responsibility to the **first party** (the Indemnifying Party) to cover costs (e.g., legal fees, damages) incurred by the other party due to the specified claims.  
   - It clarifies that the Indemnifying Party must pay awards, costs, and attorneys’ fees resulting from such claims, reinforcing the first party’s financial liability.

### 4. **Exclusions and Limitations**  
   - **Consequential damages** (e.g., lost profits) are excluded under Section 8.2, **unless** they arise from a third-party judgment covered by indemnification (Section 7.2) or a breach of confidentiality (Section 11.4). This limits the scope of indemnifiable losses.  
   - The carve-out for liquidated damages (Section 10.5.2) further refines what is/is not covered.

### 5. **Procedural Requirements**  
   - The reference to **Section 7.3 (Procedure)** implies that the Indemnified Party must follow specific steps (e.g., timely notice, cooperation) to invoke indemnification, ensuring structured enforcement.

### **Key Relevance to the Query**  
This clause directly addresses **first-party indemnification** by:  
- Defining the **indemnifying party’s obligations** for **specific claims** (third-party actions tied to their site, products, breaches, or IP infringement).  
- Explicitly **excluding certain liabilities** (e.g., consequential damages) unless tied to indemnifiable claims.  
- Providing a **framework for enforcement** (payment of awards, procedural rules).  

In summary, it is a **targeted indemnification clause** that allocates risk between parties for enumerated third-party claims while limiting exposure to broader damages.

Subject to Section 7.3 [Procedure], the Indemnifying Party will pay any award against the Indemnified Party and its Affiliates (and their respective employees, directors or representatives) and any costs and attorneys' fees reasonably incurred by them resulting from any such Claim.
explanation:
This indemnification clause is directly relevant to the query about **"first party indemnification of specified claims"** because it outlines the obligations of one party (the "Indemnifying Party") to defend, indemnify, and hold harmless the other party (the "Indemnified Party") against specific types of third-party claims. Here’s how it addresses the query:

### Key Relevance to the Query:
1. **Definition of "Claim"**:  
   - The clause defines "Claim" broadly to include any third-party claim, action, or proceeding (excluding claims by affiliates). This sets the scope for what types of disputes trigger indemnification.

2. **Specified Claims Covered**:  
   The indemnity obligation applies only to claims arising from **four specific categories**:  
   - **(a)** The Indemnifying Party’s own site operations or content (unless caused by the Indemnified Party).  
   - **(b)** The marketing/sale of products/services through the Indemnifying Party’s site (with exceptions for the Indemnified Party’s products).

   - **(d)** Intellectual Property infringement claims related to materials provided by the Indemnifying Party.  

   This ensures indemnification is **narrowly tailored** to specified scenarios, protecting the Indemnified Party from liabilities tied to the Indemnifying Party’s actions or failures.

3. **First-Party Obligation**:  
   - The clause explicitly binds the **"Indemnifying Party"** (the first party in this context) to cover costs (e.g., legal fees, damages, awards) incurred by the Indemnified Party due to the specified claims. This shifts liability to the party responsible for the underlying issue.

4. **Procedure & Scope**:  
   - The indemnity is subject to Section 7.3 (likely outlining notice requirements and defense control), ensuring structured handling of claims.  
   - It extends protection not just to the Indemnified Party but also to its affiliates, employees, and representatives, broadening the safeguard.

### Why It Answers the Query:

- The **exclusions and carve-outs** (e.g., for content/materials supplied by the Indemnified Party) ensure the indemnity is precise and fair.  

In summary, this clause provides a **targeted indemnification mechanism** where the first party (Indemnifying Party) assumes responsibility for enumerated third-party claims, protecting the counterparty from risks tied to the first party’s operations, content, or breaches.

query_id: first party indemnification of specified claims
clause: 12. Indemnification. VS shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless PPD, its affiliates, directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs, incurred by any such party as a result of any claim, action or proceeding by a third party (a "Third Party Claim") arising from VS's negligence, intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement. PPD shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless VS, its directors, officers and employees thereof for any and all damages, costs, expenses and other liabilities, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs, incurred by any such party as a result of any Third Party Claim arising from PPD's negligence, intentional misconduct, or breach of this Agreement. Either indemnified party shall give the indemnifying party prompt notice of any Third Party Claim for which indemnification is sought hereunder. The indemnifying party shall have the right to control the defense and settlement of such Third Party Claim, provided the indemnifying party shall act reasonably and in good faith with respect to all matters relating to the settlement or disposition of the claim, and the indemnified party shall reasonably cooperate in the investigation, defense and settlement of such claim. The indemnified party shall have the right to participate in, but not control, the defense and settlement of a claim and to employ separate legal counsel of its own choice; provided, however, that such employment shall be at the indemnified party's own expense, unless (i) the employment thereof has been specifically authorized by the indemnifying party, or (ii) the indemnifying party has failed to assume the defense and employ counsel (in which case the indemnified party shall control the defense and settlement of such claim).
explanation:
This **indemnification clause** is directly relevant to the query about **"first party indemnification of specified claims"** because it outlines the obligations of both parties (VS and PPD) to indemnify each other against **specific third-party claims** arising from certain wrongful acts. Here’s how it addresses the query:

### Key Elements of the Clause:
1. **First-Party Indemnification**:  
   - **VS** (the first party in this context) agrees to indemnify **PPD** (and its affiliates, directors, officers, and employees) for third-party claims arising from:  
     - VS’s **negligence**,  
     - VS’s **intentional misconduct**, or  
     - VS’s **breach of the agreement**.  
   - Conversely, **PPD** (another first party) agrees to indemnify **VS** (and its directors, officers, and employees) for third-party claims arising from PPD’s equivalent wrongful acts.

2. **Specified Claims Covered**:  
   - The indemnification applies only to **Third Party Claims** (claims brought by an external third party, not disputes between VS and PPD).  
   - The triggering events are narrowly defined: **negligence, intentional misconduct, or breach of contract**—not all possible liabilities.  

3. **Procedural Requirements**:  
   - **Notice**: The indemnified party must promptly notify the indemnifying party of a claim.  
   - **Control of Defense**: The indemnifying party has the **right to control the defense and settlement**, ensuring they can manage costs and strategy.  
   - **Cooperation**: The indemnified party must reasonably assist in the defense.  
   - **Right to Participate**: The indemnified party may join the defense at its own expense unless the indemnifying party fails to act (in which case the indemnified party takes control).  

### Relevance to the Query:  
- The clause clearly defines **which party (first party) is responsible for indemnifying the other** based on the nature of the claim.  
- It specifies **what types of claims** (third-party claims due to negligence, misconduct, or breach) trigger indemnification.  
- It includes **conditions and limitations** (notice, defense control, cooperation) that structure how indemnification operates.  

### Conclusion:  
This clause is a **mutual indemnification provision** where each "first party" (VS or PPD) agrees to protect the other against specified third-party claims caused by their own wrongdoing. It ensures that liability is allocated fairly and procedurally managed.  

Would you like any refinements or focus on a specific sub-topic?

query_id: first party indemnification of specified claims
clause:
7. Indemnification. a. A claim that a Party (referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnifying Party") is required to defend and indemnify the other Party (referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnified Party") under this Agreement is referred to at times in this Section as an "Indemnified Claim". Defense and indemnification under this Section will include, without limitation, (1) paying or reimbursing the actual, reasonable, substantiated out-of-pocket expenses incurred in connection with the investigation, defense and settlement of any civil, criminal or administrative action, suit, arbitration, mediation, hearing, audit, investigation or other proceeding threatened or commenced against an Indemnified Party on an Indemnified Claim (e.g., fees and expenses of attorneys, accountants, auditors, investigators, consulting experts, testifying experts and other consultants; fees and expenses of an arbitrator or mediator; filing fees and costs imposed by any court, administrative agency or other tribunal; etc.), and (2) satisfying any judgment, award, order, lien, levy, fine, penalty or other sanction imposed against an Indemnified Party on an Indemnified Claim. b. Seller will defend and indemnify Buyer against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Seller, including, without limitation, any product supplied by Seller which fails to conform to the representations and warranties in this Agreement; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Seller in the design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery of any product sold by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Seller under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, packaging, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement (except to the extent that the infringement is based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license terms in supplying the product); (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by a governmental authority on Buyer to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Seller of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Seller has agreed to defend and indemnify Buyer against under a Purchase Schedule. c. Buyer will defend and indemnify Seller against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Buyer; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Buyer in the purchase, storage, repackaging, resale or delivery of any product purchased from Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Buyer under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement to the extent based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license term in supplying the product; (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by governmental authority on Seller to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Buyer of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Buyer has agreed to defend and indemnify Seller against under a Purchase Schedule. d. As a condition of receiving defense and indemnification under this Section for an Indemnified Claim, the Indemnified Party must: (1) notify and tender the defense of an Indemnified Claim to the Indemnifying Party promptly after the Indemnified Party learns of the Indemnified Claim; and
(2) provide information and cooperation reasonably requested by the Indemnifying Party in the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. An Indemnifying Party will reimburse the Indemnified Party of any reasonable, actual, substantiated out-of-pocket expense incurred in providing the requested information or cooperation. e. If the Indemnifying Party accepts the tender of defense of an Indemnified Claim, with or without reservation, the Indemnifying Party will: (1) promptly notify the Indemnified Party of the acceptance of the tender of defense of the Indemnified Claim. (2) control the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim, including, without limitation, the selection of licensed, qualified and reputable attorneys and expert witnesses and all decisions over settlement and litigation strategy. The Indemnifying Party must act in good faith in exercising control over the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. (3) Provide information reasonably requested by the Indemnified Party regarding the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim f. An Indemnifying Party, acting in good faith, may settle an Indemnified Claim for which it is responsible under this Agreement involving infringement on the intellectual property of a third-party by: (1) obtaining a license from the third-party allowing the required use of its intellectual property; (2) modifying a product, equipment or process in a manner which avoids infringing on the intellectual property of the third-party; or (3) voluntarily withdrawing the infringing product from the market and either refunding the amount paid by the Indemnified Party for the infringing product or replacing the infringing product with a non-infringing product. g. The Parties may disagree on whether a claim is an Indemnified Claim under this Agreement, which Party should be considered the Indemnifying Party and Indemnified Party for an Indemnified Claim or whether each Party is partially liable for an Indemnified Claim and how liability for such an Indemnified Claim should be allocated between them. In these and other circumstances in which an actual or potential conflict of interest exists or arises between the Parties with regards to an alleged or agreed upon Indemnified Claim that would preclude their joint representation by a single defense counsel, the Parties will endeavor in good faith to attempt to resolve the conflict. If the Parties are able to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, the Parties will memorialize the agreed upon resolution in a written joint defense agreement signed by officers of each Party and their joint defense counsel. If the Parties are unable to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, each Party may independently and separately investigate, defend, settle and satisfy the claim subject to their right to pursue payment or reimbursement for costs incurred in doing so from the other Party as provided in this Agreement.
explanation:
The query asks about **"first party indemnification of specified claims,"** which refers to the obligations of one party (the "Indemnifying Party") to defend and compensate the other party (the "Indemnified Party") for certain predefined claims or liabilities. The provided **Indemnification Clause (Section 7)** comprehensively addresses this by:

### **1. Defining Indemnified Claims**  
The clause specifies that an "Indemnified Claim" arises when one party is required to defend and indemnify the other under the agreement. It outlines the scope of indemnification, including:  
- Reimbursement of legal and related expenses (e.g., attorney fees, court costs).  
- Payment of judgments, fines, or penalties imposed on the Indemnified Party.  

### **2. Specifying Claims Covered by Each Party**  
The clause **explicitly lists the types of claims** for which each party (Seller or Buyer) must indemnify the other:  

#### **Seller’s Indemnification Obligations (First Party = Seller)**  
Seller agrees to indemnify Buyer for:  
- Third-party claims for **personal injury, property damage, or loss** caused by Seller’s breach, negligence, or misconduct.  
- **Infringement claims** related to Seller’s products (unless caused by Buyer’s licensed IP).  
- **Fines/penalties** imposed due to Seller’s violation of law.  
- Any additional indemnification agreed in a Purchase Schedule.  

#### **Buyer’s Indemnification Obligations (First Party = Buyer)**  
Buyer agrees to indemnify Seller for:  
- Third-party claims for **personal injury, property damage, or loss** caused by Buyer’s breach, negligence, or misconduct.  
- **Infringement claims** to the extent they arise from Buyer’s licensed IP.  
- **Fines/penalties** imposed due to Buyer’s violation of law.  
- Any additional indemnification agreed in a Purchase Schedule.  

### **3. Conditions for Indemnification**  
The clause imposes **procedural requirements** on the Indemnified Party to qualify for indemnification:  
- **Prompt notice** of the claim to the Indemnifying Party.  
- **Cooperation** with the Indemnifying Party’s defense efforts.  

### **4. Control of Defense & Settlement**  
The Indemnifying Party has the **right to control** the defense and settlement of claims, subject to good faith obligations. It also allows for **specific remedies in IP infringement cases** (e.g., obtaining licenses, modifying products).  

### **5. Dispute Resolution for Conflicting Claims**  
If parties disagree on liability, they must attempt to resolve conflicts in good faith. If unresolved, each may defend separately and later seek reimbursement.  

### **Relevance to the Query**  
This clause **directly answers the query** by:  
- Identifying which party (first party = Seller or Buyer) must indemnify the other.  
- Enumerating the **specific claims** triggering indemnification.  
- Detailing the **process and limitations** for enforcing indemnification rights.  

Thus, it provides a **clear, structured framework** for indemnification obligations between the parties, ensuring predictability and risk allocation.

clause: Section 10. Indemnification. Each party hereto agrees to indemnify the other party and save and hold the other harmless from any and all claims, causes of action, damages, liabilities, costs, losses, and expenses (including legal costs and attorneys' fees) arising out of or connected with any claim, demand or action which is inconsistent with any of the warranties, representations, covenants or agreements which the indemnifying party has made in this Agreement. Pending the determination and settlement of any such claim, demand or action, the non-indemnifying party will have the right, at its election, to withhold payment to you of any monies otherwise payable hereunder, in an amount reasonably related to that claim, demand or action, and its estimated costs and expenses (including legal costs and attorneys' fees) in connection therewith.
explanation:
The **"first party indemnification of specified claims"** refers to one party's obligation to compensate and protect the other party from certain legal claims, losses, or liabilities as outlined in the contract.  

### **Relevance of the Clause to the Query:**  
1. **Indemnification Scope** – The clause specifies that **each party (including the "first party")** must indemnify the other for claims arising from breaches of warranties, representations, covenants, or agreements made in the contract. This directly addresses the query by defining the types of claims subject to indemnification.  

2. **Covered Claims** – The indemnification applies to **"any and all claims, causes of action, damages, liabilities, costs, losses, and expenses"** (including legal fees) tied to a breach of contractual obligations. This ensures that the indemnified party is protected from financial harm due to the indemnifying party’s misrepresentations or failures.  

3. **Withholding Right** – The clause allows the non-indemnifying party to **withhold payments** related to a disputed claim until resolution, protecting them from potential losses while the claim is pending. This is a practical enforcement mechanism for indemnification.  

4. **Mutual Obligation** – While the query focuses on "first party" indemnification, the clause is **reciprocal**, meaning both parties have the same indemnification duties. However, it can be tailored if only one party (e.g., the "first party") is required to indemnify the other.  

### **Key Takeaway:**  
This clause is highly relevant because it:  
- Defines **what claims are indemnifiable** (those contradicting contractual promises).  
- Specifies **financial protections** (covering legal costs, damages, etc.).  
- Provides a **risk-mitigation tool** (payment withholding) for pending claims.  

If the query seeks a **one-sided indemnity** (only the first party indemnifying), the clause would need modification to remove reciprocity. Otherwise, it broadly aligns with the concept of indemnifying specified claims.  

Would you like a revised version focusing solely on the first party's obligations?

Here’s the breakdown:

### **1. Limitations on Indemnification for Broad-Based Claims**  
The clause restricts the indemnifying party’s liability by:  
- **Thresholds or Deductibles (likely implied by redactions):** The indemnifying party may not be liable until certain conditions (e.g., monetary or procedural thresholds) are met.  
- **Caps on Liability:** The indemnifying party’s total liability may be limited to a specified amount (implied by references to "only for the […] of the […]").  
- **Exclusions for Certain Losses:** The clause may exclude liability for certain types of damages (e.g., indirect or consequential losses).  

These limitations help protect the indemnifying party from excessive exposure to broad-based claims (e.g., third-party claims, general breaches, or unspecified liabilities).

### **2. Exceptions to Limitations (Broad Claims Still Covered)**  
The clause explicitly **excludes** the following from the limitations, meaning the indemnifying party remains fully liable for:  
- **Fraud or Intentional Misrepresentation** (e.g., willful misconduct or deceit).  
- **Breach of Key Agreements or Covenants** (e.g., material contractual obligations).  

This ensures that the indemnifying party cannot avoid responsibility for severe or deliberate wrongdoing, even if other claims are capped.

### **Relevance to the Query**  
- The clause **balances risk allocation** by limiting exposure to broad indemnification claims while preserving liability for high-priority breaches.  
- It addresses **first-party indemnification** by defining the scope of the indemnifying party’s obligations (what they must cover and what they can limit).  
- The redacted portions likely specify financial or procedural conditions (e.g., minimum claim thresholds, baskets, or caps), which are common in indemnification clauses to prevent trivial or excessive claims.  

### **Key Takeaway**  
This clause is a **risk-management tool**—it shields the indemnifying party from unlimited liability for routine claims but ensures accountability for serious misconduct or core contractual breaches. If the query concerns how broad indemnification claims are treated, this clause answers by setting boundaries (with exceptions).

Seller will defend and indemnify Buyer against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Seller, including, without limitation, any product supplied by Seller which fails to conform to the representations and warranties in this Agreement; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Seller in the design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery of any product sold by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Seller under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, packaging, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement (except to the extent that the infringement is based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license terms in supplying the product); (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by a governmental authority on Buyer to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Seller of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Seller has agreed to defend and indemnify Buyer against under a Purchase Schedule. c. Buyer will defend and indemnify Seller against: (1) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged breach of this Agreement by Buyer; (2) any third-party claim for personal injury, damage to tangible property or other loss to the extent caused by any actual or alleged negligence or other legally culpable misconduct of Buyer in the purchase, storage, repackaging, resale or delivery of any product purchased from Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of other obligation of Buyer under this Agreement; (3) any third-party claim for actual or alleged infringement of a product sold by Seller under this Agreement or its design, manufacture, storage, sale or delivery by Seller under this Agreement or in the performance of any other obligation of Seller under this Agreement to the extent based on intellectual property that that Buyer has represented and warranted to Seller that Buyer owns and that Buyer has licensed to Seller and that Seller has used in compliance with the license term in supplying the product; (4) the threat or imposition of any fine, penalty or other sanction by governmental authority on Seller to the extent caused by any actual or alleged violation by Buyer of Applicable Law; or (5) any other matter that Buyer has agreed to defend and indemnify Seller against under a Purchase Schedule. d. As a condition of receiving defense and indemnification under this Section for an Indemnified Claim, the Indemnified Party must: (1) notify and tender the defense of an Indemnified Claim to the Indemnifying Party promptly after the Indemnified Party learns of the Indemnified Claim; and
(2) provide information and cooperation reasonably requested by the Indemnifying Party in the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. An Indemnifying Party will reimburse the Indemnified Party of any reasonable, actual, substantiated out-of-pocket expense incurred in providing the requested information or cooperation. e. If the Indemnifying Party accepts the tender of defense of an Indemnified Claim, with or without reservation, the Indemnifying Party will: (1) promptly notify the Indemnified Party of the acceptance of the tender of defense of the Indemnified Claim. (2) control the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim, including, without limitation, the selection of licensed, qualified and reputable attorneys and expert witnesses and all decisions over settlement and litigation strategy. The Indemnifying Party must act in good faith in exercising control over the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim. (3) Provide information reasonably requested by the Indemnified Party regarding the investigation, defense, settlement and satisfaction of the Indemnified Claim f. An Indemnifying Party, acting in good faith, may settle an Indemnified Claim for which it is responsible under this Agreement involving infringement on the intellectual property of a third-party by: (1) obtaining a license from the third-party allowing the required use of its intellectual property; (2) modifying a product, equipment or process in a manner which avoids infringing on the intellectual property of the third-party; or (3) voluntarily withdrawing the infringing product from the market and either refunding the amount paid by the Indemnified Party for the infringing product or replacing the infringing product with a non-infringing product. g. The Parties may disagree on whether a claim is an Indemnified Claim under this Agreement, which Party should be considered the Indemnifying Party and Indemnified Party for an Indemnified Claim or whether each Party is partially liable for an Indemnified Claim and how liability for such an Indemnified Claim should be allocated between them. In these and other circumstances in which an actual or potential conflict of interest exists or arises between the Parties with regards to an alleged or agreed upon Indemnified Claim that would preclude their joint representation by a single defense counsel, the Parties will endeavor in good faith to attempt to resolve the conflict. If the Parties are able to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, the Parties will memorialize the agreed upon resolution in a written joint defense agreement signed by officers of each Party and their joint defense counsel. If the Parties are unable to resolve the actual or potential conflict of interest, each Party may independently and separately investigate, defend, settle and satisfy the claim subject to their right to pursue payment or reimbursement for costs incurred in doing so from the other Party as provided in this Agreement.
explanation:
The query concerns **"first party indemnification of broad-based claims,"** and the provided indemnification clause is highly relevant because it outlines the scope, conditions, and procedures for indemnification between the parties (Seller and Buyer) in a contract. Here’s how the clause addresses the query:

### 1. **Definition of Indemnified Claims**  
   - The clause defines an "Indemnified Claim" as any claim where one party (Indemnifying Party) must defend and indemnify the other (Indemnified Party). This includes **broad-based claims** such as:  
     - Third-party claims (e.g., personal injury, property damage, infringement).  
     - Regulatory fines or penalties.  
     - Negligence or misconduct.  

### 2. **Scope of Indemnification**  
   The clause covers **wide-ranging liabilities**, including:  
   - **Seller’s indemnification obligations (Section b):**  
     - Product non-conformance, negligence, IP infringement, regulatory violations, and other agreed matters.  
   - **Buyer’s indemnification obligations (Section c):**  
     - Buyer’s breaches, negligence, IP claims (where Buyer provided licensed IP), and regulatory violations.  

   This demonstrates that indemnification is **not narrowly limited** but extends to **broad categories of claims** (tort, contract, IP, regulatory).  

### 3. **Procedural Safeguards for Indemnification**  
   - **Notice and Cooperation (Section d):** The Indemnified Party must promptly notify the Indemnifying Party and provide cooperation.  
   - **Control of Defense (Section e):** The Indemnifying Party controls the defense/settlement but must act in good faith.  
   - **Conflict Resolution (Section g):** If parties dispute liability, they must attempt to resolve conflicts or proceed separately while preserving reimbursement rights.  

### 4. **Broad Coverage of Losses**  
   Indemnification includes:  
   - Legal fees, expert costs, court fees, settlements, judgments, and regulatory penalties.  
   - **No carve-outs for certain claim types**, reinforcing the broad-based nature of the protection.  

### **Relevance to the Query**  
The clause explicitly structures indemnification to cover **wide-ranging claims** (not just specific breaches), ensuring the "first party" (either Seller or Buyer, depending on the claim) is protected against diverse third-party liabilities. The language is comprehensive, addressing:  
- **Third-party claims** (tort, IP, regulatory).  
- **First-party obligations** (who must indemnify whom).  
- **Procedural mechanisms** to enforce indemnification broadly.  

Thus, it directly answers the query by showing how a **first party’s indemnification duties** are defined expansively to cover **broad-based claims**.  

**Key Takeaway:** The clause is a robust, detailed indemnification framework designed to allocate risk for a wide spectrum of liabilities between contracting parties.

Any claim or action for personal injury, death, or property damage resulting from a customer's use of the Endorsed Product; or c. explanation:
The query asks about **"first party indemnification of broad-based claims,"** and the provided **Indemnification Clause (Section 15)** is a strong example of such a provision. Here’s how it aligns with the query:

### **1. First-Party Indemnification**  
The clause clearly designates the **Company (first party)** as the indemnifying party, requiring it to:  
- **Indemnify** (compensate for losses),  
- **Defend** (cover legal costs), and  
- **Hold harmless** (protect from liability)  
**North (the second party)** and its affiliates against specified claims.  

This is a classic **first-party obligation**, where one contractual party (Company) assumes liability for the other (North).

### **2. Broad-Based Coverage**  
The clause covers a **wide range of claims**, making it "broad-based" by including:  
- **Diverse claim types**: Lawsuits, assessments, penalties, damages, attorney fees, etc.  
- **Multiple scenarios**:  
  - **Misconduct claims** (negligence/intentional acts in advertising or use of North’s likeness) **(Subsection a)**.  
  - **Product liability** (injury, death, or property damage from product use) **(Subsection b)**.  
  - **Breach of contract** (violations of warranties/representations) **(Subsection c)**.  

This breadth ensures North is protected from **almost any liability tied to the Company’s actions or the endorsed product**.

### **3. Relevance to the Query**  
The clause directly addresses the query by:  
- Defining **who indemnifies whom** (first-party Company → second-party North).  
- Encompassing **wide-ranging claims** (not limited to narrow issues like IP or confidentiality).  
- Including **third-party claims** (e.g., customer lawsuits) under the indemnity umbrella.  

### **Key Takeaways**  
- **Scope**: The indemnification is **broad** (covers negligence, liability, breach, etc.).  
- **Protection**: North is shielded from **downstream risks** (e.g., customer injuries, legal violations by Company).  
- **First-Party Focus**: The Company bears the burden, aligning with standard **indemnitor-indemnitee** dynamics.  

This clause would satisfy a request for **first-party indemnification of broad-based claims**, as it allocates wide liability to the Company while protecting North comprehensively.  

Would you like any refinements to narrow or expand the coverage?

explanation:
This indemnification clause is highly relevant to the query about **"first party indemnification of broad-based claims"** because it outlines the scope and conditions under which one party (the "Indemnifying Party") must defend and indemnify the other party (the "Indemnified Party") against third-party claims. Here’s how it addresses broad-based claims:

### **1. Broad Definition of "Claim"**  
The clause defines **"Claim"** expansively to include:  
- Any **third-party claim, action, or proceeding** (excluding claims by affiliates).  
- Claims brought by **governmental authorities**, which broadens the scope to regulatory or enforcement actions.  

This ensures that indemnification covers not just private lawsuits but also **administrative, regulatory, or investigative proceedings**, making it broad-based.

### **2. Wide Coverage of Indemnifiable Scenarios**  
The indemnity obligation applies to claims arising from:  
- **Operation/content of the Indemnifying Party’s site** (unless caused by the Indemnified Party).  
- **Marketing/sale of products/services** (with carve-outs for the Indemnified Party’s contributions).  
- **Breach of representations/warranties** (including regulatory compliance obligations).  
- **IP infringement claims** related to materials provided by the Indemnifying Party.  

This **covers a broad spectrum of potential liabilities**, including contractual breaches, regulatory violations, and intellectual property disputes.

### **3. Protection for Affiliates and Representatives**  
The indemnity extends not just to the Indemnified Party but also to its **affiliates, employees, directors, and representatives**, ensuring comprehensive protection against third-party claims.

### **4. Financial Scope of Indemnification**  
The Indemnifying Party must cover:  
- **Legal costs** (attorneys’ fees).  
- **Damages, judgments, and other losses** resulting from the claim.  

This ensures that the Indemnified Party is **fully protected** from financial exposure, not just liability.

### **5. Broad but Conditional**  
While the clause is broad, it includes **limitations**:  
- Exclusions for claims caused by the Indemnified Party’s actions (e.g., materials they supplied).  
- Compliance with procedural requirements (Section 7.3, which likely includes notice and cooperation obligations).  

### **Conclusion**  
This clause provides **broad-based indemnification** by:  
✔ Covering **diverse types of claims** (legal, regulatory, IP).  
✔ Protecting **multiple related entities** (affiliates, employees).  
✔ Including **financial liabilities** (legal fees, damages).  
✔ Applying to **third-party claims** (including government actions).  

However, it is **not unlimited**—it excludes claims caused by the Indemnified Party and requires adherence to procedural safeguards. This balances broad protection with reasonable limitations.  

Would you like any refinements or a redrafted version for a different risk allocation?

iii) Application Provider will indemnify, defend and hold harmless Excite@Home, its affiliates, officers, directors, employees, consultants and agents from any and all third party claims, liability, damages and/or costs (including, but not limited to, attorneys fees) arising from:
(1) Its breach of any warranty, representation or covenant in this Agreement; or
(2) Any claim (including, without limitation, claims for infringement of third party intellectual property, publicity, or privacy rights) arising from the e-centives Content, including, without limitation, e-centives' trademarks, but excluding claims based upon the Excite Content or any other materials provided by Excite in the form originally provided by Excite; or
(3) Any claims (including, without limitation, claims for infringement of third party intellectual property, publicity, or privacy rights), by third parties arising out of or based upon e-centives' services and/or any other service provided by e-centives, but excluding claims based upon the Excite Content or any other information or materials provided by Excite in the form originally provided by Excite.
iv) Application Provider's obligation to indemnify Excite@Home is conditioned upon Excite@Home promptly notifying Application Provider of any and all such claims. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Application Provider shall only be relieved of its obligation to indemnify Excite@Home to the extent that any such failure to notify materially and adversely affects Application Provider's defense. Excite@Home will reasonably cooperate with Application Provider in the defense and/or settlement thereof; provided that, if any settlement requires an affirmative obligation of, results in any ongoing liability to, or prejudices or detrimentally impacts Excite@Home in any way, and such obligation, liability, prejudice or impact can reasonably be expected to be material, then such settlement shall require Excite@Home's written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), and Excite@Home may have its own counsel in attendance at all official proceedings and substantive negotiations relating to such claim at Excite@Home's sole cost and expense.
iii) Excite@Home will indemnify, defend and hold harmless Application Provider, its affiliates, officers, directors, employees, consultants and agents from any and all third party claims, liability, damages and/or costs (including, but not limited to, attorneys fees) arising from:
(1) Its breach of any warranty, representation or covenant in this Agreement;
(2) Any claim (including, without limitation, claims for infringement of third party intellectual property rights) arising from the Excite Content, including, without limitation, Excite's trademarks, but excluding claims based upon the e-centives Content or any other materials provided by e-centives in the form originally provided by e-centives; or
(3) Any claims (including, without limitation, claims for infringement of third party intellectual property rights), by third parties arising out of or based upon Excite@Home's services and/or any other service provided by Excite, but excluding claims based upon the e-centives Content or any other information or materials provided by e-centives in the form originally provided by e-centives.
iv) Excite@Home's obligation to indemnify Application Provider is conditioned upon Application Provider promptly notifying Excite@Home of any and all such claims. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Excite shall only be relieved of its obligation to indemnify e-centives to the extent that any such failure to notify materially and adversely affects Excite@Home's defense. Application Provider will reasonably cooperate with Excite@Home in the defense and/or settlement thereof; provided that, if any settlement requires an affirmative obligation of, results in any ongoing liability to, or prejudices or detrimentally impacts Application Provider in any way, and such obligation, liability, prejudice or impact can reasonably be expected to be material, then such settlement shall require Application Provider's written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed), and Application Provider may have its own counsel in attendance at all proceedings and substantive negotiations relating to such claim at Application Provider's sole cost and expense.

explanation:
This indemnification clause is highly relevant to the query about **"indemnification of broad-based third-party claims"** because it establishes a mutual obligation between the parties (Application Provider and Excite@Home) to defend and compensate each other against a wide range of third-party claims. Here’s how it addresses the query:

### **1. Scope of Indemnification for Third-Party Claims**  
The clause covers **broad-based third-party claims**, including:  
- **Intellectual property infringement** (e.g., patents, copyrights, trademarks).  
- **Privacy/publicity rights violations**.  
- **Claims arising from breaches of warranties or covenants** in the agreement.  
- **Claims tied to each party’s content or services** (e.g., claims against e-centives’ Content or Excite@Home’s services, but with exclusions for materials provided by the other party).  

This ensures protection against diverse legal risks posed by third parties.

### **2. Conditions for Indemnification**  
The clause specifies procedural requirements to trigger indemnification:  
- **Prompt notice** of claims (failure to notify only relieves the indemnifying party if the delay **materially harms** their defense).  
- **Cooperation** in defense/settlement (e.g., sharing information, attending negotiations).  
- **Settlement control**: If a settlement imposes material obligations or liabilities on the indemnified party, their **written consent** is required (cannot be unreasonably withheld).  

These conditions balance the interests of both parties while ensuring efficient resolution of claims.

### **3. Mutual and Symmetrical Protections**  
The clause is **reciprocal**:  
- Application Provider indemnifies Excite@Home for claims tied to its content/services (Section iii).  
- Excite@Home indemnifies Application Provider for claims tied to its content/services (mirrored in Section iii).  

This symmetry ensures neither party bears undue risk for the other’s actions or materials.

### **4. Exclusions and Limitations**  
Indemnification excludes claims based on:  
- The other party’s **original materials** (e.g., Excite@Home isn’t liable for claims stemming from Excite Content it provided, and vice versa).  
- **Implied warranties**: The clause disclaims all implied warranties (Section c), limiting indemnification to breaches of express terms.  

### **Conclusion**  
This clause comprehensively addresses **broad-based third-party claims** by:  
- Defining covered claims (IP, privacy, breaches, etc.).  
- Setting clear conditions for indemnification (notice, cooperation, settlement approval).  
- Allocating risk fairly between parties.  

It ensures both parties are protected from third-party liabilities arising from their respective obligations, content, or services, while safeguarding against unreasonable settlements or procedural failures.  

Would you like any specific aspect analyzed further?

   - **No carve-outs for consequential damages** in third-party claims: Section 8.2 clarifies that indemnification overrides the general exclusion of consequential damages, meaning the indemnifying party **must cover even indirect damages** if awarded by a court to a third party.  

### 4. **Procedural Safeguards**  
   - The reference to **Section 7.3 (Procedure)** implies there are steps (e.g., notice, control of defense) to ensure claims are handled efficiently, reducing ambiguity in enforcement.  

### Why It’s Relevant to the Query  
This clause directly addresses **broad third-party risks** by:  
- Defining claims expansively (not limited to specific issues).  
- Covering legal, financial, and operational liabilities.  
- Explicitly including governmental actions and IP disputes.  
- Overriding limitations on damages when third parties are involved.  

It’s a robust example of how contracts allocate risk for **wide-ranging third-party claims**, ensuring one party doesn’t bear costs for the other’s actions.

(3) Any claims (including, without limitation, claims for infringement of third party intellectual property, publicity, or privacy rights), by third parties arising out of or based upon e-centives' services and/or any other service provided by e-centives, but excluding claims based upon the Excite Content or any other information or materials provided by Excite in the form originally provided by Excite.
20. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
Except as provided by Sections 19(a)(iii)(2), (a)(iii)(3), (b)(iii)(2) and (b)(iii)(3):
a) Neither party will have liability for any damages other than direct damages. In no event will either party be liable to the other for any special, incidental or consequential damages, whether based on breach of contract, tort (including negligence) or otherwise, whether or not that party has been advised of the possibility of such damage.
b) Either party's liability for damages shall be limited to the amounts actually paid by the other party.
explanation:
This clause is highly relevant to the query about **"indemnification of broad-based third-party claims"** because it explicitly outlines the scope and limitations of indemnification obligations for third-party claims. Here’s how it addresses the query:

### 1. **Broad Coverage for Third-Party Claims**  
   - The clause requires the **Application Provider** (e-centives) to indemnify Excite@Home and its affiliates against **"any and all third-party claims"**, including liability, damages, and legal costs (e.g., attorneys' fees).  
   - The coverage is broad, encompassing claims arising from:  
     - Breach of warranties/representations in the agreement (Section 19(a)(iii)(1)).  
     - Intellectual property (IP), publicity, or privacy rights violations related to e-centives' content/services (Sections 19(a)(iii)(2) and (3)).  
     - Claims tied to e-centives' trademarks or services, excluding Excite-provided materials.  

### 2. **Exclusions and Limitations**  
   - The indemnification **excludes claims based on Excite’s content or materials** (as originally provided by Excite). This carves out liability for third-party claims stemming from Excite’s own actions.  
   - The **Limitation of Liability clause (Section 20)** further narrows the scope:  
     - Liability is generally restricted to **direct damages** (no consequential/incidental damages).  
     - However, **indemnification obligations under Sections 19(a)(iii)(2) and (3) are exempt** from this limitation, meaning the Application Provider remains fully liable for third-party IP/privacy claims.  

### 3. **Key Takeaways for the Query**  
   - **Broad-Based Claims**: The clause covers a wide range of third-party claims (IP, privacy, breach of contract) but is not unlimited—it excludes Excite’s own content.  
   - **Defense Obligation**: The Application Provider must **defend** (not just indemnify) Excite@Home, adding proactive legal protection.  
   - **Survival of Indemnity**: Unlike general liability caps, indemnification for third-party claims survives the limitation clause, ensuring robust protection for Excite@Home.  

### Why This Matters  
For a party seeking indemnification against broad third-party risks (e.g., IP lawsuits, privacy violations), this clause provides strong safeguards while balancing exclusions for the other party’s (Excite’s) own liabilities. The carve-outs in Section 20 ensure that indemnification for third-party claims remains enforceable even when other damages are capped.

query_id: indemnification of broad-based third party claims
clause:
ARTICLE X INDEMNIFICATION
Section 10.1 Network Affiliate Indemnification. Network Affiliate shall defend, indemnify, and hold harmless NCM and its officers, directors, shareholders, contractors, employees, representatives, agents, successors, and assigns (collectively, "Representatives") from and against any and all losses, obligations, risks, costs, liabilities, settlements, damages, judgments, awards, fines, penalties, and expenses (including, without limitation, reasonable attorneys' fees) (collectively, "Costs") suffered or incurred in connection with or as a result of, and from and against any and all third party claims, suits, actions, or proceedings actually or allegedly arising out of, based upon, or relating to, (i) any breach by Network Affiliate of Article IX, (ii) infringement by any information, content or other materials supplied by or on behalf of Network Affiliate hereunder (including the Brand) of any third party U.S. patent, trademark, or copyright right arising from NCM's use of such materials in accordance and compliance with this Agreement, provided such Costs have been finally awarded by a court of competent jurisdiction or approved by Network Affiliate as part of a settlement, (iii) any use of any NCM Property other than as authorized by this Agreement, or (iv) Network Affiliate's fraud, willful misconduct, or noncompliance with law.
Section 10.2 NCM General Indemnification. NCM shall defend, indemnify, and hold harmless Network Affiliate and its Representatives from and against any and all Costs suffered or incurred in connection with or as a result of, and from and against any and all third party claims, suits, actions, or proceedings actually or allegedly arising out of, based upon, or relating to, (i) any breach by NCM of Article IX, or (ii) NCM's fraud, willful misconduct, or noncompliance with law.
Section 10.3 NCM Infringement Indemnification.
(a) Indemnifications Obligations. NCM shall defend, indemnify and hold harmless Network Affiliate and its Representatives from and against any and all Costs suffered or incurred arising from any and all third party claims, suits, actions, or proceedings to the extent actually or allegedly arising out of, based upon, or relating to any infringement by the NCM Property (but excluding any Equipment) of any third party U.S. trademark, copyright, or patent issued as of the Effective Date, arising from Network Affiliate's use of the NCM Property in accordance and compliance with this Agreement.
(b) Additional Remedies. In addition to, but not in limitation of, NCM's obligations under Section 10.3 (a) above, NCM may, at its sole option, in the event that any claim, suit, proceeding, or action is brought or threatened for which NCM may be obligated under Section 10.3 (a) to indemnify Network Affiliate: (i) replace or modify the NCM Property to render it non-infringing; (ii) secure for Network Affiliate the right to use the NCM Property; or (iii) terminate this Agreement under the provisions of Article X. In the event NCM chooses to terminate this Agreement under Article X hereof, NCM shall refund to Network Affiliate the portion (if any) of the total amount of license fees actually paid to NCM by Network Affiliate hereunder during the two-year period immediately preceding the date of the claim for indemnification, depreciated according to a five-year straight line depreciation.
(c) Limitations of Obligations. NCM shall not have any liability to Network Affiliate under this Section 10.3 for any alleged infringement based in any part on: (i) any Service content or Confidential Information supplied by or on behalf of Network Affiliate; (ii) the combined use of the NCM Property with software or hardware products or other technology or materials not provided or owned by NCM; (iii) additions or modifications to the NCM Property not made by NCM; (iv) use or installation of the NCM Property in accordance with designs or specifications not provided by NCM; or (v) use of any legacy or superseded version of NCM Property if such infringement would have been avoided by use of a more recent version of the NCM Property made available to Network Affiliate. The obligations under this Section 10.3 state the entire liability of NCM and are Network Affiliate's sole and exclusive remedies, with respect to intellectual property infringement.
Section 10.4 Defense of Action. A Party offering indemnification or defense under this Article X (each, an "Indemnitor") shall have the right to control the defense and settlement of any and all claims, suits, proceedings, and actions for which such Indemnitor is obligated to indemnify, hold harmless, and defend hereunder, but the Party or Representative of a Party receiving such indemnification or defense under this Article X (each, the "Indemnitee") shall have the right to participate in such claims, suits, proceedings, and actions at its own cost and expense. An Indemnitor shall have no liability under this Article unless the Indemnitee gives notice of such claim to the Indemnitor promptly after the Indemnitee learns of such claim so as to not prejudice the Indemnitor. Under no circumstance shall either party hereto settle or compromise or consent to the entry of any judgment with respect to any claim, suit, proceeding, or action that is the subject of indemnification hereunder without the prior written consent of the other party, which consent shall not be withheld or delayed unreasonably.
explanation:
The query concerns **"indemnification of broad-based third-party claims,"** and the provided clause (Article X) comprehensively addresses this issue by outlining the indemnification obligations between **Network Affiliate** and **NCM** for third-party claims. Here’s how the clause aligns with the query:

### **1. Scope of Indemnification for Third-Party Claims**  
The clause explicitly covers **"any and all third-party claims, suits, actions, or proceedings"** (Sections 10.1, 10.2, and 10.3), which aligns with the **broad-based** nature of the query. The indemnification obligations extend to:  
- **Legal costs** (attorneys' fees, settlements, judgments, etc.).  
- **Various liabilities** (infringement, breach of contract, fraud, noncompliance with law).  

### **2. Broad Coverage of Scenarios**  
The indemnification provisions are structured to cover a **wide range of third-party claims**, including:  
- **Intellectual Property (IP) Infringement** (Sections 10.1(ii) and 10.3(a)) – Claims arising from trademark, copyright, or patent violations.  
- **Breach of Contract** (Sections 10.1(i) and 10.2(i)) – Claims due to violations of Article IX.  
- **Fraud, Willful Misconduct, or Illegal Acts** (Sections 10.1(iv) and 10.2(ii)) – Claims stemming from unlawful behavior.  
- **Unauthorized Use of Property** (Section 10.1(iii)) – Claims from misuse of NCM’s assets.  

### **3. Defense and Settlement Rights** (Section 10.4)  
- The **Indemnitor (defending party)** has the **right to control the defense and settlement** of third-party claims.  
- The **Indemnitee (protected party)** may participate but **at its own expense**.  
- **Prompt notice** is required to avoid prejudicing the Indemnitor.  
- **No settlement without consent** (preventing unilateral resolutions that could harm the other party).  

### **4. Limitations and Exclusions** (Section 10.3(c))  
While broad, the indemnification has **reasonable carve-outs**, such as:  
- No liability for infringement caused by **Network Affiliate’s modifications** or **unauthorized combinations** with third-party products.  
- **No obligation** if the claim could have been avoided by using an updated version of NCM’s property.  

### **Conclusion**  
This indemnification clause is **highly relevant** to the query because it:  
✔ **Broadly covers third-party claims** (IP, breach, misconduct, etc.).  
✔ **Defines defense and settlement procedures** (control, notice, consent).  
✔ **Balances obligations with reasonable limitations** (excluding scenarios where the indemnitee is at fault).  

Thus, it provides a **comprehensive framework** for handling **broad-based third-party claims** while protecting both parties’ interests.
